Samples are field filtered for dissolved or not filtered for total, and preserved with K2Cr2O7/H2SO4 to pH <2.  The organomercury compounds are oxidized via a H2SO4/KMnO4/K2S2O8 digestion.  The mercury compounds are then reduced to elemental mercury. A stream of synthetic air introduced into the system passes through a reference cell and then, after sparging the elemental mercury from the solution, passes through the sample cell.  A UV monitor possessing a mercury lamp provides the light source and the absorbance at 253.7 nm is measured against the reference.

Samples are field filtered for dissolved or not filtered for total, and preserved with K2Cr2O7/H2SO4 to pH <2.  The organomercury compounds are oxidized via a H2SO4/KMnO4/K2S2O8 digestion.  The mercury compounds are then reduced to elemental mercury. A stream of synthetic air introduced into the system passes through a reference cell and then, after sparging the elemental mercury from the solution, passes through the sample cell.  A UV monitor possessing a mercury lamp provides the light source and the absorbance at 253.7 nm is measured against the reference.

Soil and sediment samples are air dried, ground, and digested with aqua regia.  The organomercury compounds are oxidized via a H2SO4/KMnO4/K2S2O8 digestion.  The mercury compounds are then reduced to elemental mercury.  A stream of synthetic air introduced into the system passes through a reference cell and then, after sparging the elemental mercury from the solution, passes through the sample cell.  A UV monitor possessing a mercury lamp provides the light source and the absorbance at 253.7 nm is measured against the reference.

Vegetation samples are air dried, ground, and digested with H2SO4/HNO3.  The organomercury compounds are oxidized via a H2SO4/KMnO4/K2S2O8 digestion.  The mercury compounds are then reduced to elemental mercury.  A stream of synthetic air introduced into the system passes through a reference cell and then, after sparging the elemental mercury from the solution, passes through the sample cell.  A UV monitor possessing a mercury lamp provides the light source and the absorbance at 253.7 nm is measured against the reference.

Animal tissues are not dried.  They are homogenized and digested with H2SO4/HNO3.  The organomercury compounds are oxidized via a H2SO4/KMnO4/K2S2O8 digestion.  The mercury compounds are then reduced to elemental mercury.  A stream of synthetic air introduced into the system passes through a reference cell and then, after sparging the elemental mercury from the solution, passes through the sample cell.  A UV monitor possessing a mercury lamp provides the light source and the absorbance at 253.7 nm is measured against the reference.

Aliquots of sample are reacted with Folin phenol reagent (a mixture of tungstic and molybdic acids) and, after time for reaction, with carbonate solution.  The absorbance of the developed colour is measured at 700 nm using a spectro-photometer equipped with 1 cm cells.  It should be emphasized that the reaction is not specific for lignin or tannin.  Automated procedure.

A well mixed sample is introduced into a graduated Imhoff cone and allowed to stand for an hour (with gentle spinning of the cone at 45 minutes to minimize entrapped pockets of water).  The volume of settled residue is recorded and reported as mL/L.
EPA Method 101A particulate and gaseous mercury emissions

APHA 10200 I Ash-free dry weight is determined gravimetrically after drying the submitted sample at 105?C. The residue is then ignited at 500?C and the ash rewetted to restore water of hydration to clays and other minerals. The ash weight is determined gravimetrically after bringing the rewetted ash to constant weight at 104?. The ash-free dry weight is the difference between the dry weight and the ash weight.
Observed Property ID: Ash free dry weight in biota (mass)

Method Description: A well-mixed volume of the sample is filtered through a Whatman GF/C glass fibre filter (1.2um particle retention).  The filtrate is collected in a flask and transferred to a clean, pre-weighed porcelain dish that has been muffled at 550C for 20 minutes; the dish containing the filtrate is then placed overnight in an oven set at 90-95C to permit the liquid to evaporate.  The dish with the filterable residue is dried at 103C for one hour and weighed again to determine the total filterable residue(FR).
Grav.Gooch Cruc.550C

Residue from determination of residue, non-filterable, is ignited to constant weight at 550 C in a muffle furnace.  Usually, a 15 to 20 minute ignition is required.  The ignited residue is cooled in a desiccator and weighed.  The cycle of igniting, cooling, desiccating and weighing is repeated until a constant weight is attained.

Residue from determination of residue, non-filterable, is ignited to constant weight at 550 C in a muffle furnace.  Usually, a 15 to 20 minute ignition is required.  The ignited residue is cooled in a desiccator and weighed.  The cycle of igniting, cooling, desiccating and weighing is repeated until a constant weight is attained.

DCM Extraction, Column clean-up, isotope dilution GC/HRMS. Method Reference: USEPA 1613B. Methodology: Samples are filtered if required. Solids are extracted by Soxhlet using toluene. The liquid portion is extracted by liquid/liquid extraction using dichloromethane. The extracts are prepared using column chromatography, reduced in volume and analyzed by isotope-dilution GC/HRMS.

The electrical conductance is measured using a conductivity bridge which has been calibrated with KCl solutions of known concentration.  Salinity is determined by reference to the Practical Salinity Scale, 1978.

Light is directed through a tube containing the sample, and the relative intensity of the scattered light, at 90 degrees to the light source, is measured by photocells.  An instrument designed to do this is called a nephelometer, which is calibrated with a standard formazin reference suspension.  The instrument readout is in terms of Nephelometric Turbidity Units (NTU), or the equivalent formazin turbidity units (FTU) or the equivalent Jackson Turbidity Units (JTU).
Nephel.Double Beam
The acidity (pH 4.5) is determined by manual potentiometric titration of a sample aliquot with a standard solution of alkali to pH 4.5.
Manual Potentiometric Titration with standard solution to specified pH.  The sample must not be filtered, diluted, concentrated, or altered in any way.
Manual Potentiometric Titration with standard solution to specified pH.  The sample must not be filtered, diluted, concentrated, or altered in any way.

Alkalinity is determined by potentiometric titration with sulfuric acid which has been standardized with sodium carbonate.  The sample (if pH>8.3) is first titrated to a pH=8.3, which corresponds to the equivalence point for the conversion of carbonate to bicarbonate ion (phenolphthalein alkalinity).  The titration is continued to a pH of 4.5, which corresponds approximately to the equivalence point for the conversion of bicarbonate ion to carbonic acid (entire titration indicates total alkalinity).  An extrapolation technique based on the near proportionality of concentration of hydrogen ions to excess of titrant beyond the equivalence point.  The amount of standard acid required to reduce pH exactly 0.30 pH (i.e. pH 4.2) unit is measured carefully.  Because this change in pH corresponds to an exact coupling of the hydrogen ion concentration, a simple extrapolation can be made to the equivalence point.  The actual pH of the stoichiometric end point in alkalinity determinations is the pH at which the inflection in the titration curve occurs and is directly related to the amount of carbonate alkalinity orginally present in the sample.  A curve can be constructed by plotting pH versus mL of acid to find this point directly.  To obtain the actual substances contributing to alkalinity, such a curve should be constructed.
Filt; Colour Comparator

This analysis is carried out in accordance with the extraction procedure outlined in "Test Methods for Evaluating Solid Waste - Physical/Chemical Methods Volume 1C" SW-846 EPA Method 1311, published by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  Thisple is extracted at a 20: 1 liquid to solids ratio for 16 to 20 hours using either extraction fluid #1 (glacial acetic acid, water and sodium hydroxide) or extraction fluid #2 (glacial acetic acid), depending on the pH of the original sample.  The extract is then filtered through a 0.6 to 0.8 micron glass fibre filter and analysed using inductively coupled plasma - optical emission spectrophotometry (EPA Method 6010B)
Observed Property ID: pH of the Extraction Fluid used for EPA TCLP extraction (acidity)

The ortho-phosphate reacts with ammonium molybdate and antimony tartrate in an acidic medium to form an antimony-phosphomolybdate complex, which is reduced to an intensely blue coloured complex by ascorbic acid.  The absorbance of this complex is measured at 880 nm.

Phosphorus present in the sample is converted to soluble ortho-phosphate by digesting the sample with persulphate in an acidic medium.  The resulting ortho-phosphate then reacts with ammonium molybdate and antimony tartrate in an acidic medium to form an antimony-phophomolybdate complex, which is reduced to an intensely blue coloured complex by ascorbic acid.  The absorbance of this complex is measured at 880 nm.

Phosphorus present in the sample is converted to soluble ortho-phosphate by digesting the sample with persulphate in an acidic medium.  The resulting ortho-phosphate then reacts with ammonium molybdate and antimony tartrate in an acidic medium to form an antimony-phophomolybdate complex, which is reduced to an intensely blue coloured complex by ascorbic acid.  The absorbance of this complex is measured at 880 nm.

After being passed through a cation-exchange column, the sample is reacted with an alcohol solution of barium chloride and methylthymol blue (MTB) at pH 2.5-3.0 to form barium sulfate.  The pH of this solution is raised to 12.5-13.0 so that the excess barium reacts with MTB.  The uncomplexed MTB is equivalent to the amount of sulfate present.
Titr.Iodine

The ortho-phosphate reacts with ammonium molybdate and antimony tartrate in an acidic medium to form an antimony-phosphomolybdate complex, which is reduced to an intensely blue coloured complex by ascorbic acid.  The absorbance of this complex is measured at 880nm.  Note that for low level analyses are performed on the entire bottle of sample, not on an aliquot from the bottle.

Method 1630 of the US EPA. Samples are distilled under an inert gas flow to isolate methylmercury and minimize matrix interferences. The distillate is analyzed by aqueous phase ethylation, purge and trap, desorption and GC separation. THe separated species are then pyrolized to elemental Hg and quantified by cold vapour atomic flourescence spectroscopy.

THe separated species are then pyrolized to elemental Hg and quantified by cold vapour atomic flourescence spectroscopy.

This method describes the spectrophotometric analysis of chlorophyll a derived from material retained on a 0.45 um filter.  The filter is ground and extracted in 90% acetone.  Absorbances of the extract are read at 750, 664, 646 and 630 nm.  The abbreviation "SU" stands for Scor-Unesco method of calculating chlorophyll.  The method is the "Trichromatic Method" of determining chlorophyll, whereby, samples are not acidified and corrected for the presence of phaeophytin, but determines chlorophyll a, b, & c respectively by inserting the corrected optical densities in 3 separate equations.  The "N. Acid" used to stand for extract "Not-acidified" when determining chlorophyll a.  This method does not correct for the presence of phaeophytin.  Acidification is used only when determining Phaeophytin.  "Acid" means extract is acidified in order to determine chlorophyll a in the presence of phaeophytin, and the method is called the Lorenzon method.  The optical densities read and equations used to calculate chlorophyll a are slightly different.  This method corrects for the presence of phaeophytin.  The terms SU and SP are synonymous, the method calculation is done by the "Scor-Unesco" (SU) written by Strickland & Parsons (SP).

Spectrophotometric analysis of chlorophyll a derived from material scraped from substrate and retained on a 0.45 um filter.  The filter is ground and extracted into 90% acetone.  The absorbances of the extract are read at 750, 664, 646 and 630 nm.  "N. Acid." (= not acidified) methods are not corrected for phaephytin; "Acid." (=acidified) methods are corrected for phaeophytin.

Water samples are filtered through glass fibre filters and then frozen.  Foam plugs are usually cut from a block with a cork borer of known diameter.  The cells are disrupted by ultrasonification and the Chlorophyll is extracted with an aqueous Magnesium Caronate: Acetone mixture.  Absorbance measured at about 750, 664, 646 and 630 nm before and after acidification with a few drops of HCl.  "LOR." indicates Lorenzen calculation.  The addition of acid to a Chlorophyll solution removes the bonded Magnesium of the Porphyrin ring thus converting it to Phaeophytin.  This method is single filter.

For Total Volatile Residue (parm=0032): A known volume of a well-mixed sample is transferred into an pre-ignited porcelain dish, evaporated at 90 - 95 C, dried at 103 C, cooled and weighed.  The porcelain dish with dried and weighed residue is then ignited in a muffle at 550 C and weighed again.  The difference in weights represents Total Volatile Residue (TVR). The Total Fixed Residue (TFR) is the portion of sample left after ignited at 550 C.

For Total Volatile Residue (parm=0032): A known volume of a well-mixed sample is transferred into an pre-ignited porcelain dish, evaporated at 90 - 95 C, dried at 103 C, cooled and weighed.  The porcelain dish with dried and weighed residue is then ignited in a muffle at 550 C and weighed again.  The difference in weights represents Total Volatile Residue (TVR). The Total Fixed Residue (TFR) is the portion of sample left after ignited at 550 C.

The chromium VI in the sample is reacted with diphenylcarbazide in an acid solution to produce a red-violet colour. The intensity of the colour is measured at 540 nm. Sample is lab or field filtered and not acid preserved.

Samples are field filtered for dissolved or not filtered for total, and preserved with K2Cr2O7/H2SO4 to ph <2.  The organomercury compounds are oxidized via a H2SO4/KMnO4/K2S2O8 digestion.  The mercury compounds are then reduced to elemental mercury.  A stream of synthetic air introduced into the system passes through a reference cell and then, after sparging the elemental mercury from the solution, passes through the sample cell.  A UV monitor possessing a mercury lamp provides the light source and the absorbance at 253.7 nm is measured against the reference.

MPN Completed

Water samples are filtered through glass fibre filters and then frozen.  Foam plugs are usually cut from a block with a cork borer of known diameter.  The cells are disrupted by ultrasonification and the Chlorophyll is extracted with an aqueous magnesium Carbonate: Acetone mixture.  By measuring the maximum Absorbance at about 663 nm before acidification and at about 665 nm after acidification the amount of Chlorophyll and Phaeophytin present in the sample can be calculated.  The addition of acid to a Chlorophyll solution removes the bonded Magnesium of the Porphyrin ring thus converting it to Phaeophytin.  This method uses a single plug.

A lead oxide plate is exposed to ambient air for a period of 30 days.  During this time sulfur dioxide and sulfur trioxide in the atmosphere are collected by lead oxide as the result of both oxidation and absorption processes and converted to lead sulfate.
The lead oxide plates undergo extractions and the sulfate ion is converted to a barium sulfate suspension under controlled conditions.  The resulting turbidity is determined using a spectrophotometer and compared to a curve prepared from standard sulfate solutions.  Preliminary results are reported as mg/l, and loading results as mg/dm2/d.

A calcium oxide plate is exposed to ambient air for a period of 30 days.  During this time fluoride in the ambient air is collected as calcium fluoride.  The plates undergo an extraction and the fluoride which is isolated is determined using the selective ion electrode procedure.

A 10.4 cm (4.1") diameter polyethylene canister containing a collection medium is exposed to the ambient air for a period of approximately 30 days.  The sample subsequently undergoes gravimetric and/or chemical analysis in the laboratory, plus loading calculation.  The prepared sample (see Dustfall Total procedure) is passed through a 0.45 um membrane filter.  A portion of the filtrate is then evaporated on an oven; the portion which dries to constant weight at 105C constitutes the soluble particulate.

A 10.4 cm (4.1") diameter polyethylene canister containing a collection medium is exposed to the ambient air for a period of approximately 30 days.  The sample subsequently undergoes gravimetric and/or chemical analysis in the laboratory, plus loading calculation.  The prepared sample (see Dustfall-Total procedure) is passed through a 0.45 um membrane filter.  A portion of the filtrate is then evaporated in a oven; the portion which ignites to constant weight at 550C constitutes the ashed soluble particulate.  It should be noted that if the ashed soluble particulate procedure is completed, this will preclude phosphorus and metal analysis.

Method Name: Soluble Particulates Pkg. Ion Chrom. Anions
Method Description: For the Soluble Particulates Pkg., a portion of filtrate from the Particulate-Total procedure made up to 500 mL is analyzed by Ion Chromatography.  Intermediate results are in mg/L.  Loading results are then calculated with units of mg/dm2/d.  Note that the air-convention is to report on basis of ion weight not element, e.g. as NO3 for nitrate, and as PO4 for phosphate.

A glass electrode, calibrated with a pH 4.10 H2SO4 buffer, is used with a digital pH/mV meter to measure sample pH.  Acidity is then determined on the same aliquot by titration with uL incrments of 0.01N NaOH.  The volume of NaOH added to the sample is plotted against the Gran's function, calculated from the readings obtained during the titration.  Equivalence point for strong acidity is obtained by extrapolating the Gran's functions to the volume axis.  Total alkalinity is determined in a similar manner using 0.01N H2SO4.

Low ionic strength glass electrode (Radiometer PHC 2701 or equivalent).  Calibrate with low ionic strength buffers.  Measurement accuracy and precision to be +- 0.01 pH unit or better.  Measurements made at 25 C or results are temperature corrected to 25 C.  Code "PH--" must be used for precipitation and code "0004" must be used for surface waters.

(a) For the Soluble Particulates Pkg., a portion of filtrate from the Particulate-Total procedure made up to 500 mL is analyzed by Ion Chromatography.  Intermediate results are in mg/L.  Loading results are then calculated with units of mg/dm2/d.  
(b) For precipitation samples, samples and standards are spiked with concentrated carbonate/bicarbonate solution to give the sample the same background as the eluent used (avoiding a "water dip" effect).  The anions of interest are separated through an anion "guard" and anion "separator" column.  An anion micro membrane suppressor following the separator columns is used to reduce the background eluent conductivity by converting the carbonate and bicarbonate species to carbonic acid, while enhancing the conductivity of the ions of interest by converting these ions to their corresponding acids.  A conductivity detector senses the same species in direct proportion to their initial concentration.
(c) For HiVol samples, discs are cut from the HiVol filter, extracted with DI water, and anions analyzed by ion chromatograph, Preliminary results are reported in mg/L and intermediate HiVol loading results are reported as ug/m3.
(*) Note that the air-convention is to report on basis of ion weight not element, e.g. as NO3 for nitrate, and as PO4 for phosphate.

(a) For the Soluble Particulates Pkg. a portion of filtrate from the Particulate - Total procedure made up to 500 mL is analyzed by IC.  Intermediate results are reported in mg/L.  Loading results are calculated and reported with units of mg/dm2/d.(b) For precipitation samples, all samples are filtered through a 0.22 um fritted glass filter prior to injection.  The cations of interest are separated through a cation "guard" and cation "separator" column with a methane sulphonic acid eluent.  After the cations are separated they exit at various times from the column in a background of eluent.  A self regeneration membrane suppressor is attached to the end of the column to neutralize the acid before detection, and form the corresponding hydroxide. Note that ammonium is reported as NH4 not as N.  (c) For HiVol samples, discs cut from the HiVol filter are extracted with DI water and the soluble anions are analyzed by IC.  Intermediate results are reported in units of mg/L and HiVol loading results are reported as ug/m3.

For air particulate a 10.4 cm cannister containing a collection medium is exposed to the ambient air for a period of approximately 30 days.  The prepared sample undergoes a sulfuric acid persulfate digestion to oxidize organically bound phosphorus to phosphate and also to hydrolyse polyphosphates to ortho-phosphate, which is then determined colorimetrically as heteropoly molybdophosphoric acid.  Intermediate results are reported with units of mg/L and loading results with units of mg/dm2/d.  Note that the air convention is to report as ion weight, ie as PO4 not as P.

Intermediate results are reported with units of mg/L and loading results with units of mg/dm2/d.  Note that the air convention is to report as ion-weight, ie PO4 not as P.

This analysis is carried out using procedures adapted from Alberta Environment Method No. 51515. Gran Alkalinity is determined by titrating with strong acid to pH 4.0, purging with nitrogen gas to remove CO2, and back-titrating with strong alkali to pH 5.6. Gran Alkalinity is expressed as negative H+ milli-equivalent/L (-H+ meq/L).

PM10 is the designation for particulate matter in the atmosphere that has an anerodynamic diameter of 10 micrometers (um) or less for method PM10 5305.  A high volume (HV) PM10 sampler draws a known volume of ambient air at a constant flow rate through a size selective inlet and through one or more filters.  Particles in the PM10 size range are then collect on the 8X10 filter(s) during the specified 24 hour sampling period.  Each sample filter is weighted before and after sampling to determine the net weight (mass) gain of the collected PM10 sample.  For method TP-T 5305, a high volume (HV) sampler draws a known volume of ambient air at a constant flow rate through one or more filters. Particles are then collected on the 8X10 filter(s) during the specified 24 hour sampling period.  Each sample filter is weighed before and after sampling to determine the net weight (mass) gain of the collected total particulate sample.  For method PM02 5305, a measured volume of ambient air is drawn through an inlet that passes only particles less than 2.5 um.  The particulate which is collected on a 0.3 micron teflon coated borosilicate 8X10 glass filter constitutes PM02 particulate.

PM10 is the designation for particulate matter in the atmosphere that has an anerodynamic diameter of 10 micrometers (um) or less for method PM10 5305.  A high volume (HV) PM10 sampler draws a known volume of ambient air at a constant flow rate through a size selective inlet and through one or more filters.  Particles in the PM10 size range are then collect on the 8X10 filter(s) during the specified 24 hour sampling period.  Each sample filter is weighted before and after sampling to determine the net weight (mass) gain of the collected PM10 sample.  For method TP-T 5305, a high volume (HV) sampler draws a known volume of ambient air at a constant flow rate through one or more filters. Particles are then collected on the 8X10 filter(s) during the specified 24 hour sampling period.  Each sample filter is weighed before and after sampling to determine the net weight (mass) gain of the collected total particulate sample.  For method PM02 5305, a measured volume of ambient air is drawn through an inlet that passes only particles less than 2.5 um.  The particulate which is collected on a 0.3 micron teflon coated borosilicate 8X10 glass filter constitutes PM02 particulate.

xml:space="preserve">
PM10 is the designation for particulate matter in the atmosphere that has an anerodynamic diameter of 10 micrometers (um) or less for method PM10 5305.  A high volume (HV) PM10 sampler draws a known volume of ambient air at a constant flow rate through a size selective inlet and through one or more filters.  Particles in the PM10 size range are then collect on the 8X10 filter(s) during the specified 24 hour sampling period.  Each sample filter is weighted before and after sampling to determine the net weight (mass) gain of the collected PM10 sample.  For method TP-T 5305, a high volume (HV) sampler draws a known volume of ambient air at a constant flow rate through one or more filters. Particles are then collected on the 8X10 filter(s) during the specified 24 hour sampling period.  Each sample filter is weighed before and after sampling to determine the net weight (mass) gain of the collected total particulate sample.  For method PM02 5305, a measured volume of ambient air is drawn through an inlet that passes only particles less than 2.5 um.  The particulate which is collected on a 0.3 micron teflon coated borosilicate 8X10 glass filter constitutes PM02 particulate.

For methods TP-T 5306 and PM10 5306, a measured volume of air is drawn through a 47 mm filter rather than through 8x10 filters as for TP-T 5305 and PM10 5305.  Air particulate is trapped on a pre-weighed Teflon filter.  The weight change after sampling is used to calculate the particulate in ug/m3.

For methods TP-T 5306 and PM10 5306, a measured volume of air is drawn through a 47 mm filter rather than through 8x10 filters as for TP-T 5305 and PM10 5305.  Air particulate is trapped on a pre-weighed Teflon filter.  The weight change after sampling is used to calculate the particulate in ug/m3.

For methods TP-T 5306 and PM10 5306, a measured volume of air is drawn through a 47 mm filter rather than through 8x10 filters as for TP-T 5305 and PM10 5305.  Air particulate is trapped on a pre-weighed Teflon filter.  The weight change after sampling is used to calculate the particulate in ug/m3.

EPA 9095B (mod)  Free Liquids are determined by the Paint Filter Test, where a specified amount of material is placed in a paint filter. If any portion of the test material passes through the filter in the five minute test period, the material is deemed to contain free liquids. The absence of any amount of free liquid classifies the sample as a solid.

Method Description: Sample is derivatized and injected directly. Each compound is separated by reversed phase HPLC and analyzed by Electro Spray Ionization MS/MS detection using Triple Quadrupole MS/MS detector. Internal standards are used for quantitation.

The phenolic compounds are removed from the sample interferences by means of on-line distillation under acidic conditions.  The distillate is subsequently reacted with 4-aminoantipyrine and an alkaline ferricyanide to form a red complex which is measured colourimetrically at 505 nm.  This method is applicable to the analysis of drinking, surface and saline waters, domestic and industrial wastes and acid rain (atmospheric deposition).
Automated 4-APP; dist

Metallocyanide compounds are converted to simple cyanides by means of on-line UV irradiation and distillation under acidic conditions.  The hydrogen cyanide is subsequently reacted with chloramine-T to form cyanogen chloride which reacts with pyridine and barbituric acid to form a red coloured complex which is measured colorimetrically at 570nm.  Interferences are eliminated or reduced to a minimum by the on-line distillation procedure.  Sulfide interferences may be eliminated by precipitating samples suspected of high H2S levels with the addition of PbCO3.  This procedure does yield positive CN result for thiocyanate.

The sample is distilled from a phosphoric acid medium into a phosphate buffer solution (pH 5.2).  Simple cyanides, eg,. those that distill from the phosphoric acid solution without any ultraviolet irradiation, are absorbed into the phosphate buffer solution after distillation.  The cyanide in the buffer solution is converted to cyanogen chloride, (CNCI) by reaction with chloramine-T.  The CNCI then forms a red coloured complex on addition of the pyridine-barbituric acid reagent and the absorbance is measured at 580 nm.  The Konig (1,2) synthesis first described the specific and quantitative reaction of cyanogen halides to cleave pyridine to produce glutaconic aldehyde.  This reaction has been applied to the determination of cyanide by oxidation of CN- to cyanogen halide, CNX, in which CN+ is the reactive species.  The CN+ reacts with pyridine to produce an intermediate which hydrolyzes to a conjugated dialdehyde, glutaconic aldehyde.  The glutaconic aldehyde is then coupled with a primary amine, of a compound containing reactive methylene hydrogens (RH2), barbituric acid in this case (3).

A sample is placed in a sample tube then acidified and sealed to a collection tube containing a sodium hydroxide trapping solution.  The tube is placed in a block heater and distilled through a hydrophobic membrane.  The distillate is then analyzed for strong acid dissociable (SAD) cyanide by acid distillation / UV irradiation followed by an automated colourimetric determination

Method Description: Sediment samples are shaken with a mixture of Dichloromethane, Methanol and Sulphuric Acid, filtered, then extracted with Dichloromethane.  After concentration, the extract is methylated using ethereal Diazomethane.  Extracts are cleaned up as required using Florisil.  The extracts are analyzed for Acid Extractable Herbicides using GC/MS.

Silver in Tissue by CRC ICPMS (WET)               Methodology: This method is conducted following British Columbia Lab Manual method "Metals in Animal Tissue and Vegetation (Biota) - Prescriptive". Tissue samples are homogenized and sub-sampled prior to hotblock digestion with nitric and hydrochloric acids, in combination with addition of hydrogen peroxide.  Instrumental analysis is by collision cell inductively coupled plasma - mass spectrometry (modified from EPA Method 6020A).  Method Limitation: This method employs a strong acid/peroxide digestion, and is intended to provide a conservative estimate of bio-available metals.  Near complete recoveries are achieved for most toxicologically important metals, but elements associated with recalcitrant minerals may be only partially recovered.

COLOURIMETRY ON AN AUTOANALYZER WITH AMMONIUM MOLYBDATE AND   SNCL2. H2SO4 AND K2S2O8 SOLNS. ARE ADDED TO AN ALIQUOT OF THE SHAKEN SAMPLE, WHICH IS THEN BOILED 90 MIN., THE VOL. OF   THE ALIQUOT IS MAINTAINED. THEN, IF TURBID, THE ALIQUOT IS   PASSED THROUGH A 0.45 U MEMBRANE FILTER. THE FILTRATE IS   MIXED WITH A PREMIXED SOLN. OF (NH4)6MO7O24 AND SNCL2. THE RESULTING MOLYBDENUM BLUE COLOUR IS   MEASURED SPECTROPHOTO-METRICALLY AT 660 MU AND COMPARED WITH THOSE OF IDENTICALLY PREPD. STD. PO4 ION SOLNS. AND REAGENT BLANKS. INTERFEREN-CES: HG CONCN. OF 1 MG/L, AS.   REF: ANALYTICAL METHODS MANUAL, WATER QUALITY BRANCH,   ENVIRONMENT CANADA, OTTAWA, 1974

METHOD FOR THE DETERMINATION OF BACTERIAL POPULATIONS BY THE BIOLOGICAL ACTIVITY REACTION TEST? APPLICATION: This method determines the activity of bacterial populations in water, including drinking water, surface water (ponds, lakes, creeks etc.), raw water, ground water, wastewater, swimming pools and whirlpools. PRINCIPLE: Aliquots of water samples are inoculated in Biological Activity Reaction Test (BART?) vials specific to the desired organism type and incubated for eight days at room temperature. The reaction pattern is observed each day of the incubation period to determine the community activity and characteristics. Each vial type contains selective culture media specific to enriching and isolating the desired microbial community and therefore a different reaction pattern. The concentration, as colony forming unit per millilitre (cfu/mL), of the bacterial population can be extrapolated from the activity level based on the time delay for when a positive reaction is first observed in the reaction vial. METHOD SOURCES: The CARO-EDM method is performed without significant modification according to: 1. Droycon Bioconcepts Inc., Biological Activity Reaction Test BART? User Manual, 2004 Edition  Supporting Documentation: CARO-EDM Microbiology Procedures Manual, CE-PM-009-current, BART-SOFT Version 6.  Equipment Manuals: Autoclave ? Sanyo, Model 2400, or equivalent.  DETECTION LIMITS: Reporting Detection Limits (RDL) are dictated by the method and are based on an 8 day incubation period and may be lowered if the incubation period is extended. Table 2 lists the RDLs of the BART tests commonly performed by CARO-EDM. These detection limits are derived from the BART-SOFT version 6 population calculator. Refer to the CARO LIMS database for RDLs for those parameters not listed here. LAB-BART? Type RDL (cfu/ml)* IRB=34, SRB=31, HAB=65, DN=18.

Method Name: CRC ICPMS - run RAW for Br and I: unfiltered: unpreserved
Method Description: This method is applicable to water samples as well as digests of solid samples with the exception of Br and I which is only applicable to un-digested un-preserved water samples. Water samples are analyzed for dissolved metals following sample filtration or for total metals following sample preservation or digestion with the exception of water samples for Bromine and Iodine which does not require any sample preparation and only cold preservation.         This method describes the multi-elemental determination of trace elements by Collision/Reaction Cell (CRC) ICP-MS. Ions produced by radio-frequency inductively coupled plasma are measured. Analyte species originating in a liquid are pneumatically nebulized and the resulting aerosol transported by argon gas into the plasma torch. The ions produced are entrained in the plasma gas and extracted, by means of a differentially pumped vacuum interface, into a mass spectrometer. The ions flow through a Collision/Reaction Cell (CRC) where, depending on the mode of analysis, they either pass through the cell unhindered (no gas - classical ICP-MS mode) or collision/reaction chemistry takes place between the ions and an introduced gas such as hydrogen or helium. The ions are then sorted according to their mass-to-charge ratios by a quadrupole mass spectrometer. The ions transmitted through the quadrupole are quantified by a channel electron multiplier and the ion information is processed by a data handling system. Although most polyatomic interferences are removed, any additional interferences must be assessed and valid corrections applied or the data flagged to indicate problems. Interference correction must include compensation for background ions contributed by the plasma gas, reagents, and constituents of the sample matrix. Instrument drift as well as suppression or enhancement of instrument response caused by the sample matrix must be corrected for by the use of internal standards.

Dissolved and extractable water samples are ready for analysis once collected.  Total samples are autoclaved with HNO3 and hydrochloric acid (HCl) in capped Teflon vials.  Analysis is performed via Inductively Coupled Argon Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES) (simultaneous multielement analysis), Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (GF-AAS) (low level analysis) and/or Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (F-AAS).  Total Hardness is calculated from dissolved Calcium and dissolved Magnesium according to the following formula: Total Hardness=2.497248*Ca + 4.116885*Mg  (where Total Hardness is expressed as mg/L of CaCO3, and Calcium and Magnesium are expressed as mg/L Ca and mg/L Mg respectively.  Check Media/Pres. codes for consistency with regard to acid preservation.

This analysis is carried out using procedures from CSR Analytical Method: "Strong Acid Leachable Metals (SALM) in Soil", BC Ministry of Environment, 26 June 2009, and procedures adapted from EPA Method 200.2.  The sample is manually homogenized, dried at 60 degrees Celsius, sieved through a 63 um (230 mesh) sieve, and a representative subsample of the dry material is weighed.  The sample is then digested at 95 degrees Celsius for 2 hours by block digester using concentrated nitric and hydrochloric acids.  Instrumental analysis is by  atomic absorption spectrophotometry (EPA Method 245.7). Method Limitation: This method is not a total digestion technique.  It is a very strong acid digestion that is intended to dissolve those metals that may be environmentally available.  By design, elements bound in silicate structures are not normally dissolved by this procedure as they are not usually mobile in the environment. Deviation from Reference Method: This procedure deviates from the BC CSR SALM method, which specifies sieving to 2 mm (10 mesh).

Mercury in Water, Leachates and Liquids by Bromination and Cold Vapour Atomic Fluorescence Spectroscopy   PURPOSE/PRINCIPLE OF METHOD: Chemically generated bromine is used to oxidize all organic and inorganic forms of mercury in aqueous samples to mercury (II). Excess bromine is neutralized with hydroxylamine hydrochloride. The solution is introduced into a gas liquid separator and mixed with stannous chloride to reduce the mercury to its elemental form. The mercury is then purged from the solution with argon gas and passes through an atomic fluorescence detector where it absorbs light from a mercury vapour lamp that fluoresces at 254 nm. This is detected and amplified by a photo-multiplier tube in the detector. SCOPE: The method applies to the determination of field filtered, dissolved and total mercury in water, wastewater, effluent, as well as hot acid digested liquids and aqueous waste leachates generated by Leachate Extraction Procedure, Toxicity Characteristic Leaching Procedure (TCLP), Synthetic Precipitation Leaching Procedure (SPLP) and Simultaneously Extractable Metals (SEM) extracts. DETECTION LIMITS: Routine RDL = 0.02 ug/L Ultra-Low level RDL = 0.002 ug/L REFERENCE: Determination of Mercury in Water by Semi-Automated Cold Vapor Atomic Fluorescence Spectrometry. EPA Method 245.7, Revision 2, February 2005

Ambient air is drawn through a pre-packed silica gel cartridge coated with acidified 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine (DNPH) reagent, at a sampling rate of 500 - 1200 mL/min.  Aldehydes and ketones readily form a stable derivative with DNPH reagent.  These derivatives are analyzed using HPLC.  This method uses a coated adsorbent for sampling formaldehyde.  The reaction of organic carbonyl compounds (aldehydes and ketones) with DNPH-coated cartridges in the presence of acid, forms a stable derivative.  The sampling method gives a time weighted average and can be used for a 1 - 24 hours ambient air sampling time where the concentration of formaldehyde is in the low ppb (1 - 20 v/v) range or for short term (5 - 60 min) of source-impacted atmosphere where the concentration is in the ppm range.  Sampling flow rate is limited to 1.5 L/min because of the high pressure drop across the DNPH-coated silica gel cartridges.  This procedure is therefore not compatible with pumps used in personal sampling equipment.

Following the manufacturer's instructions, the probe with oxygen permeable membrane is calibrated against air or samples of known DO concentration (e.g. from Winkler titrations).  The samples are then measured for DO, again following all precautions recommended by the manufacturer to insure acceptable results.

Samples are processed, inoculated into a series of fermentation tubes followed by incubation and subsequent inoculations dependent on the target orgniams. Fermentation tubes exhibiting positive reactions proceed to confirmation steps specific to the target organism.
CSSS Ch. 15 (mod)/APHA 2510 (mod)

Conductivity (1: 10 Soil: Water Extraction). Conductivity, also known as Electrical Conductivity (EC) or Specific Conductance, is measured by immersion of a conductivity cell with platinum electrodes into a soil sample that has been added in a defined ratio of soil to deionized water, then leached prior to analysis. Conductance is measured in the fluid that is observed in the upper layer.

MEND (mod)/APHA 2510 (mod): Conductivity; also known as Electrical Conductivity (EC) or Specific Conductance; is measured by immersion of a conductivity cell with platinum electrodes into an extract from a soil sample that has been added in a 3: 1 ratio of deionized water to soil; then leached and the extract filtered prior to analysis. Conductivity measurements are temperature-compensated to 25C.

Total Solids (TS) are determined by drying a pre-weighed sample in a pre-weighed dish to constant weight in an oven at 104 ? 1?C. The increase in weight over that of the empty dish represents the total solids. Results are reported as the percentage of the total sample.

Fixed Solids (FS) are determined by drying a pre-weighed sample in a pre-weighed dish to constant weight in an oven at 104 ? 1?C. This residue is ignited to constant weight at 550?C. The remaining solids represent the Fixed Solids (FS). Results are reported as the percentage of the total solids.

CSSS (1978) 3.81 (mod): Loss On Ignition (LOI) is determined by drying a portion of an air dried and ground sample at 105?C; then igniting at 420?C for 2 hours.  The weight loss after ignition is reported as % loss on ignition.  LOI is reported on a dry weight basis. LOI at 420?C can be considered an estimation of Organic Matter Content according to Alberta Agriculture (1988).

Method Description: BC MINISTRY OF ENERGY AND MINES A sample is extracted with water at a 3: 1 liquid to solid ratio for 24 hours; then filtered through a 0.45 micron membrane filter.  Analysis is by autotitration.

APHA 5550 B-Colorimetry This analysis is carried out using procedures adapted from APHA Method 5550 B.  "Tannin & Lignin ".  Both lignin and tannin contain aromatic hydroxyl groups that react with Folin phenol reagent (tungstophosphoric and molybdophosphoric acids) to form a blue color suitable for the estimation of tannin and lignin concentrations.  However; the reaction is not specific for lignin or tannin; nor for compounds containing aromatic hydroxyl groups; in as much as many other reducing materials; both organic and inorganic; respond similarly.

E611S: Dimethyl selenide and dimethyl diselenide are analyzed by static headspace GC-MS. Samples are prepared in headspace vials and are heated and agitated on the headspace autosampler; causing VOCs to partition between the aqueous phase and the headspace in accordance with Henry`s law.

Method Name: Resins & Fatty Acids are methylated then analyzed by GCMS
Method Description: EPA 8270E; AB Env. 129; NCASI RA/FA-85.02 (mod) Resins & Fatty Acids are methylated then analyzed by GCMS. Total fatty acids is the sum of arachidic acid; behenic acid; lauric acid; lignoceric acid; linoleic acid; linolenic acid; myristic acid; oleic acid; palmitic acid; and stearic acid. Total resin acids is the sum of abietic acid; 12-chlorodehydroabietic acid; 14-chlorodehydroabietic acid; dehydroabietic acid; 12; 14-dichlorodehydroabietic acid; isopimaric acid; levopimaric acid; neoabietic acid; palustric acid; pimaric acid and sandaracopimaric acid. Total resin acids (BC WWQG) is the sum of abietic acid; neoabietic acid; pimaric acid; isopimaric acid; and sandaracopimaric acid.

Total fatty acids is the sum of arachidic acid; behenic acid; lauric acid; lignoceric acid; linoleic acid; linolenic acid; myristic acid; oleic acid; palmitic acid; and stearic acid. Total resin acids is the sum of abietic acid; 12-chlorodehydroabietic acid; 14-chlorodehydroabietic acid; dehydroabietic acid; 12; 14-dichlorodehydroabietic acid; isopimaric acid; levopimaric acid; neoabietic acid; palustric acid; pimaric acid and sandaracopimaric acid. Total resin acids (BC WWQG) is the sum of abietic acid; neoabietic acid; pimaric acid; isopimaric acid; and sandaracopimaric acid.

Method Name: EPH: Hexane micro-extrn: GC/FID (Waters: w/o Si-Gel)
Method Description: A single extraction using a small volume of hexane is conducted within the original sample container using vigorous mechanical agitation.  A portion of the hexane extract is concentrated by evaporation if necessary, and is analyzed by capillary column gas chromatography with flame ionization detection.  Test results for EPHw10-19 and EPHw19-32 are not corrected for PAHs.  LEPHw and HEPHw are EPHw10-19 and EPHw19-32 minus the concentrations of applicable PAHs found in each fraction.  Performance Based Method, revision date Nov 1, 2015.

Phenol, sodium nitroprusside, and an oxidizing solution composed of sodium hypochlorite in a basic citrate solution are sequentially added to the sample.  Under basic conditions, ammonia reacts with phenol and is oxidized by sodium hypochlorite to form an organic complex, indophenol blue.  The blue colour formed is intensified with sodium nitroprusside, and the absorbance of the resulting complex is measured at 630 nm.  Sodium citrate complexes calcium and magnesium ions and prevents precipitation of their respective hydroxides.  A heating coil is used to accelerate the colour development.

Phosphorus present in the sample is converted to soluble ortho-phosphate by digesting the sample with persulphate in an acidic medium.  The resulting ortho-phosphate then reacts with ammonium molybdate and antimony tartrate in an acidic medium to form an antimony-phosphomolybdate complex, which is reduced to an intensely blue coloured complex by ascorbic acid.  The absorbance of this complex is measured at 880 nm.

Phosphorus present in the sample is converted to soluble ortho-phosphate by digesting the sample with persulphate in an acidic medium.  The resulting ortho-phosphate then reacts with ammonium molybdate and antimony tartrate in an acidic medium to form an antimony-phosphomolybdate complex, which is reduced to an intensely blue coloured complex by ascorbic acid.  The absorbance of this complex is measured at 880 nm.

The Total Nitrogen present in the sample is oxidized to nitrate by digesting the sample with potassium persulphate in an alkaline medium.  The resulting Nitrate is reduced to Nitrite by passing it through a column containing granulated copper-cadmium.  The nitrite then reacts with sulfanilamide under acidic conditions to form a diazo compound.  This compound then complexes with N-1-naphthylethylenediamine dihydrochloride to form a reddish-purple azo dye, the absorbance of which is measured at 550nm.

The sample is refluxed for 1 hour in the presence of hydroxylamine hydrochloride/hydrochloric acid.  This digestion medium minimizes the Fe-catalyzed decomposition of CNS.  Simple cyanides and some complex metal cyanides eg. Cd, Cu, Ni, Zn react to produce HCN gas.  The HCN generated reacts instantaneously with nickel ions in an ammoniacal solution to form the ionic tetracyanonickelate(II) anion complex, Ni(CN)4-2, which has a characteristic ultra-violet spectrum, and is measured at 267 and 284 nm.  Note that thiocyanates do not react under these test conditions, but can cause positive bias if metal complexed cyanide is present.

The Total Nitrogen present in the sample is oxidized to nitrate by digesting the sample with potassium persulphate in an alkaline medium.  The resulting Nitrate is reduced to Nitrite by passing it through a column containing granulated copper-cadmium.  The nitrite then reacts with sulfanilamide under acidic conditions to form a diazo compound.  This compound then complexes with N-1-naphthylethylenediamine dihydrochloride to form a reddish-purple azo dye, the absorbance of which is measured at 550 nm.
Samples containing nitrogen compounds are digested and oxidized in-line to nitrate at 95 degrees Celsius by using an alkaline persulfate digestion solution and ultraviolet (UV) radiation.
Samples containing nitrogen compounds are digested and oxidized in-line to nitrate at 95 degrees Celsius by using an alkaline persulfate digestion solution and ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

Static headspace analysis is a method for the determination of volatile compounds in liquids and/or solids by analysing the vapour phase of a sample in a closed system; in this case a sealed vial.  Static Headspace is sometimes referred to as Equilibrium Headspace because the vapour phase above the sample in a sealed vial is brought into thermodynamic equilibrium with the sample prior to analysis.  Volatile organic compounds are thermally extracted from the sample matrix by Static Headspace sampling and introduced directly to a thick-film megabore GC column.  Compounds eluting from the GC column are introduced into a Mass Spectrometer and target compounds are identified by a comparison of both retention times and mass spectra with those of reference standards stored in a computerized data system.  Reference retention times and mass spectra for analytes are obtained by the measurement of calibration standards under precisely the same extraction conditions used for samples.  The concentration of each identified component is measured by relating the response of the sample quantitation mass ions to the response of the quantitation mass ions of a series of external standards.  A deuterated surrogate recovery standard is added to provide information on matrix effects.

Reference retention times and mass spectra for analytes are obtained by the measurement of calibration standards under precisely the same extraction conditions used for samples.  The concentration of each identified component is measured by relating the response of the sample quantitation mass ions to the response of the quantitation mass ions of a series of external standards.  A deuterated surrogate recovery standard is added to provide information on matrix effects.

Static headspace analysis is a method for the determination of volatile compounds in liquids and/or solids by analysing the vapour phase of a sample in a closed system; in this case a sealed vial.  Static Headspace is sometimes referred to as Equilibrium Headspace because the vapour phase above the sample in a sealed vial is brought into thermodynamic equilibrium with the sample prior to analysis.  Volatile organic compounds are thermally extracted from the sample matrix by Static Headspace sampling and introduced directly to a thick-film megabore GC column.  Compounds eluting from the GC column are introduced into a Mass Spectrometer and target compounds are identified by a comparison of both retention times and mass spectra with those of reference standards stored in a computerized data system.  Reference retention times and mass spectra for analytes are obtained by the measurement of calibration standards under precisely the same extraction conditions used for samples.  The concentration of each identified component is measured by relating the response of the sample quantitation mass ions to the response of the quantitation mass ions of a series of external standards.  A deuterated surrogate recovery standard is added to provide information on matrix effects.

Effluent samples are first adjusted to pH 9 and then extracted with Diethyl Ether.  The extracts are rotary evaporated and the resulting residues, containing the Resin Acids and other solvent soluble organics are then redissolved in Methanol, transferred to small glass vials, methylated with Diazomethane then evaporated to dryness under Nitrogen.  [Methylation Reaction  R-COOH(Resin/Fatty Acids) + CH2N2(Diazomethane) = R-COOCH3(Methyl ester) + N2)  The residue is re-dissolved in Methyl t-Butyl Ether (MTBE) and injected on a High Resolution Gas Chromatograph/Low Resolution Mass Spectrometer (HRGC/LRMS) system for analysis.  LRMS data is acquired in Total Ion Mode (TIM) and quantitation is performed using selected mass ions.  Positive identification of the various Resin Acids is made on the basis of a comparison of absolute retention times to those of the external standards and computer based mass spectral mass/intensity library matching routines.

Water samples are spiked with a deuterated PAH Recovery Standards mix just prior to extraction with Empore extraction disks.  Disks are eluted with Dichloromethane (DCM) and the extract concentrated.  Deuterated PAH Internal Standards are added and the extract analyzed using High Resolution Gas Chromatography / Low Resolution Mass Spectrometry (HRGC/LRMS).  MS data is acquired in Total Ion Mode (TIM) and quantitation is by multilevel Internal Standards.  Recovery efficiency is calculated and reported but results are not recovery corrected.

A portion of the sample is placed on the window of the refractometer and the salinity is determined by reading a scale from one end of the refractometer, similar to viewing through a telescope.

A homogeneous sample is filtered through a 5.5 cm Whatman GF/C glass fibre filter (1.2 um particle retention) that has been muffled at 550 C for 20 minutes and pre-weighed.  For fixed non-filterable residue (FNFR) analysis, the filter with the residue is then dried at 103 C for one hour and weighed once again to constant weight.  The filter with dried and weighed residue is then ignited in a muffle at 550 C to determine FNFR.  For fixed filterable residue (FFR) analysis, evaporated overnight at 90-95C, then dried for 1 hour at 103C and weighed for total filterable residue (FR), then ignited for 1 hour at 550C to determine FFR.  Volatile residue is the difference in weights after drying at 103 C and asking at 550 C.

The sample is refluxed for 1 hour in the presence of Zinc Acetate and Sodium Acetate buffer of pH 4.5.  Zinc Acetate is added to render Iron Cyanide insoluble.  Simple cyanides and some of the complex metal cyanides (eg., Cd, Cu, Ni, Zn) react to produce HCN gas.  The HCN produced reacts with the Ni ions in the tetranickelate solution to form the ionic tetracyanonickelate(11) anion complex, Ni(CN)4-2, which has a characteristic ultra-violet spectrum.

An Azure-A dye is added to an acidified sample forming a blue complex which is subsequently extracted into Chloroform.  Standards, made using Sodium Lauryl Sulfate, are extracted similarly.  The Absorbance of the Chloroform extracts is measured on a UV-VIS spectrophotometer at 623 nm.  The concentration of LAS equivalents in the sample is determined by comparison of the sample Absorbance to a standard curve.  Surfactants may be cationic, anionic, or non-ionic.  This method is a measure of anionic surfactants.

Effluent and swab samples are extracted with hexane, the extract concentrated, and then treated using Florisil, concentrated Sulfuric Acid, activated Copper and Mercury (as required) to remove interferences.  The samples are then analysed using Megabore Column Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture Detection.  Oil samples are first diluted with Hexane then treated in the manner outlined for effluent and swab samples.  The samples are then analysed using Megabore Column Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture Detection.

Freon 113 soluble compounds are extracted from an acidified effluent sample and made up to a measured volume.  Sediment samples are acidified then extracted using a wrist-action shaker.  The "Oils and Greases" content of the Freon extracts is determined using an Infrared Spectrophotometer with commercial quantitation software.  Quantitation is based on the comparison of the Absorbance difference between samples and a synthetic oil standard.  As there is no sample Absorbance band at 4000 cm-1 it represents a useful reference value to compensate for minor differences between spectrophotometer quartz cells.  Sample Absorbance at 2935 cm-1 represents the C-H stretching frequency of the aliphatic hydrcarbons of which typical environmental "Oils and Greases" are comprised.  "Hydrocarbons" are quantitated in the same manner after treating the Freon 113 extract with Silica Gel.

"Hydrocarbons" are quantitated in the same manner after treating the Freon 113 extract with Silica Gel.

Mercury in organic and inorganic compounds is oxidized to mercuric ions by addition of sulfuric acid, nitric acid, potassium persulfate and heat.  The mercuric ions are reduced to Hg(0) with SnCl2, are sparged from the solution with argon, and passed through a fluorescence cell in the light path of a mercury lamp.  The fluorescence at the 253.7 nm mercury emission line by Hg(0) is proportional to the concentration of mercury in the sample.

Mercury in organic and inorganic compounds is oxidized to mercuric ions by addition of sulfuric acid, nitric acid, potassium persulfate and heat.  The mercuric ions are reduced to Hg(0) with SnCl2, are sparged from the solution with argon, and passed through a fluorescence cell in the light path of a mercury lamp.  The fluorescence at the 253.7 nm mercury emission line by Hg(0) is proportional to the concentration of mercury in the sample.

Sulfide ion is measured potentiometrically using a sulfide ion-selective electrode in conjuction with a double-junction, sleeve type reference electrode.  Potentials are read using a pH metre having an expanded millivolt scale capable of being read to the nearest 0.1 mV.  Samples are treated prior to analysis with sulfide anti-oxidant buffer (SAOB).  This buffer fixes the solution pH at a highly alkaline level, and contains ascorbic acid to retard air oxidation of sulfide ion in solution.  This ensures that sulfide present occurs chiefly as S= ion rather than as complexed HS- or H2S which are present at lower pH values.  The sulfide ion concentration is measured indirectly by observing the silver ion activity in the sample.  (Because of the extreme insolubility of silver sulfide, if either ion is present in a solution the other is absent.)  A minute quantity of silver ions is released to the sample from the solid silver sulfide membrane of the electrode.  These ions set up a potential with the silver ions in the internal reference solution.  The silver ion activity in the sample is dependent on the sulfide ion activity in the sample.  The relationships of the two ion activities is: E = Eb - 2.3* RT/nF* log As  (where E=measured total potential of the system; Eb=the portion of the total potential due to the reference electrode and its filling solution; As=the activity of the sulfide ion in the sample; 2.3* RT/nF=Nernst factor)  The potential (E) for each standard is plotted linearly against concentration on a log scale to produce a standard curve.

Dissolved and extractable water samples are ready for analysis once collected.  Total samples are autoclaved with HNO3 and hydrochloric acid (HCl) in capped Teflon vials.  Analysis is performed via Inductively Coupled Argon Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES) (simultaneous multielement analysis), Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (GF-AAS) (low level analysis) and/or Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (F-AAS).  Note that extractable samples are acidified with 0.5 mL HNO3 per 100 mL of sample at time of sample collection.

Effluent samples are diluted with Acetone and analysed using direct injection into a High Resolutioin Gas Chromatograph using Flame Ionization Detection (HRGC-FID).

Effluent samples are solvent extracted with Hexane and the extract dried over Sodium Sulfate, concentrated and cleaned up, as required, using Florisil, activated Copper metal, concentrated Sulfuric Acid and Mercury, to remove interferences.  The extracts are then analysed using megabore column Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture detection.

A measured volume of sample is acidified and extracted with Methylene Chloride.  For samples which have a high organic content that potentially produce chromatographic interferences an initial pre-extraction under basic conditions is performed.  The sample extract is then evaporated to small volume and analysed by High Resolution Gas Chromatography / Low Resolution Mass Spectrometry (HRGC/LRMS).  LRMS data is acquired in Total Ion Mode (TIM) and quantitation is performed using a single mass ion.  Positive Identification of the various target compounds is made by comparison of absolute retention times to those of standards combined with computer based mass spectral mass/intensity library searching and matching routines.

LRMS data is acquired in Total Ion Mode (TIM) and quantitation is performed using a single mass ion.  Positive Identification of the various target compounds is made by comparison of absolute retention times to those of standards combined with computer based mass spectral mass/intensity library searching and matching routines.

Effluent samples to be analysed for Chlorinated Phenols are acidified with dilute Sulfuric Acid and extracted with Diethyl Ether.  After concentration the extract is methylated using ethereal Diazomethane and cleaned up with concentrated Sulfuric Acid and Mercury.  The extracts are analysed for Chlorinated Anisoles and/or Chlorinated Phenols using High Resolution Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture detection.

The extracts are analysed for Chlorinated Anisoles and/or Chlorinated Phenols using High Resolution Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture detection.

Most types of organic matter, and any elements with a lower oxidation potential than chromium, are oxidized by boiling in a mixture with known excess of potassium dichromate and sulfuric acid and the excess dichromate is titrated with ferrous ammonium sulfate (FAS).  The amount of oxidizable organic matter is proportional to the potassium dichromate consumed.  Silver sulfate is added as a catalyst so that refractory organics such as acetic acid, which are biologically available to stream organisms, are included in the oxidation.  With the catalyst, other compounds such as cellulose, which are not part of the immediate biochemical load, are also included.  Any relationships among COD and BOD or any other tests are fortuitous, because condition of the test tend to give results indicating the susceptibility of a given sample to oxidation under specified conditions that are different for each test.  (Note: This procedure is NOT appropriate for seawater.)

There is no acid digestion required for this analysis.  A water sample is collected and preserved in 0.2 percent nitric acid.  To analyse the extractable metals the sample is shaken, allowed to sit for at least twenty four hours, and a decanted portion is introduced to the spectrometer.  When the dissolved metals are required, the samples must first be filtered through a 0.45 micron cellulose acetate filter paper and then followed by preservation in 0.2 percent nitric acid.  It is important to note that different laboratories may have very different detection limits for some variables analyzed by ICPMS.

For the determination of total recoverable elements in water or waste water, take 100 ml aliquot from a well mixed, acid preserved, sample containing not more than 0.25% (w/v) total solids and transfer to a 250 ml Griffin beaker.  (If total solids are greater than 0.25% reduce the size of the aliquot by a proportionate amount). Add 1 ml of conc. nitric acid and 0.5 ml conc. hydrochloric acid.  Heat on a hot plate until the volume has been reduced to 15-20ml, ensuring that the sample does not boil. Allow to cool and transfer to a 50 ml volumetric flask.  Dilute to volume with ASTM type I water.  Centrifuge the sample or allow to stand overnight to separate insoluble material. Prior analysis, pipette 20 ml into a 50 ml volumetric flask and dilute to volume with ASTM type I water.  Analysis should be performed within seventy two hours of the completed preparation.  Note that different laboratories may have very different field preservation, digestion procedures and detection limits for this method, so these should be documented.

For the determination of total recoverable elements in water or waste water, take 100 ml aliquot from a well mixed, acid preserved, sample containing not more than 0.25% (w/v) total solids and transfer to a 250 ml Griffin beaker.  (If total solids are greater than 0.25% reduce the size of the aliquot by a proportionate amount). Add 1 ml of conc. nitric acid and 0.5 ml conc. hydrochloric acid.  Heat on a hot plate until the volume has been reduced to 15-20ml, ensuring that the sample does not boil. Allow to cool and transfer to a 50 ml volumetric flask.  Dilute to volume with ASTM type I water.  Centrifuge the sample or allow to stand overnight to separate insoluble material. Prior analysis, pipette 20 ml into a 50 ml volumetric flask and dilute to volume with ASTM type I water.  Analysis should be performed within seventy two hours of the completed preparation.  Note that different laboratories may have very different field preservation, digestion procedures and detection limits for this method, so these should be documented.

Potassium Carbonate is dissolved in a measured volume of neutralized sample.  Any Chlorophenols in the solution are then chloroacetylated in situ with Chloroacetic Anhydride in the presence of Petroleum Ether (30-60 C).  The Petroleum Ether extract is dried over anhydrous Sodium Sulfate, evaporated to small volume and analysed using High Resolution Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture Detection (HRGC-ECD).

Potassium Carbonate is dissolved in a measured volume of neutralized sample.  Any Chlorophenols in the solution are then chloroacetylated in situ with Chloroacetic Anhydride in the presence of Petroleum Ether (30-60 C).  The Petroleum Ether extract is dried over anhydrous Sodium Sulfate, evaporated to small volume and analysed using High Resolution Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture Detection (HRGC-ECD).

A known aliquot of a well mixed sample of fresh water, industrial waste, mine effluent previously preserved with sodium hydroxide, is centrifuged and acidified with nitric acid to a pH 2.  Known aliquot of ferric nitrate is added to the acidified sample and absorbance recorded at 480 nm.

Method Name: Gravimetric: GF/C glass Fiber Filt: 1-hr settling period
Method Description: (This method is verified for parm=0023 Settleable Solids).  The gravimetric analysis is performed by determining the amount of non-settleable solids that remains in suspension after one hour; this is measured by filtering a portion of the supernatent liquid through a GF/C glass fiber filter.  The amount of non-settleable solids is then subtracted from the total non-filterable residue (NFR) to give the settleable residue.

The water sample is digested with potassium persulphate and concentrated hydrochloric acid.  Samples, blanks and standards are placed in an automatic sampler and analyzed by emission spectroscopy utilizing induction coupled argon plasma as an excitation source.  All forms of arsenic, selenium and antimony are broken down with acidic persulphate to arsenate, selenate and antimonate.  Sodium borohydride is required to reduce the arsenate to arsenite.  Hydrochloric acid reduces the selenate to selenite.  Potassium iodide is required to reduce the antimonate to antimonite.  Hydrides of arsenic, selenium and antimony are formed by the action of sodium borohydride in an acidic medium, and analysed by inductively coupled argon plasma optical emission spectrometry.

Dissolved and extractable water samples are ready for analysis once collected.  Total samples are autoclaved with HNO3 and hydrochloric acid (HCI) in capped Teflon vials.  Analysis is performed via Inductively Coupled Argon Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES)(simultaneous multielement analysis), Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (GF-AAS) (low level analysis) and/or Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (F-AAS).

Method Name: Whole Bottle: Grav.: whole bottle: 1.2 um GF filter: 103-5C
Method Description: The entire bottle sample is filtered through a Whatman GF/C glass fibre filter (1.2 u particle retention) that has been muffled at 550C for 20 minutes and pre-weighed.  The filter with the residue is then dried at 103C for one hour and weighed once again to constant weight; the resulting weight differences gives the total non-filterable residue (NFR).

A homogeneous sample aliquot is filtered through a Whatman GF/C glass fibre filter (1.2 u particle retention) that has been muffled at 550C for 20 minutes and pre-weighed.  The filter with the residue is then dried at 103C for one hour and weighed once again to constant weight; the resulting weight differences gives the total non-filterable residue (NFR).

Manual potentiometric titration with solution of standard acid or of standard base to specified endpoints.  For acidity determinations, the pH of the sample is determined and a measured amount of standard acid is added, as needed, to lower the pH to 4 or less.  Hydrogen peroxide is added, the solution boiled for several minutes, cooled and titrated to pH 8.3 with standard base.  The method measures the mineral acidity of the sample plus acidity from oxidation and hydrolysis of polyvalent cations, including salts of iron and aluminum.  Because the color change of phenolphthalein indicator is close to pH 8.3, this value generally is accepted as a standard end point for titration of total acidity, including CO2 and most weak acids.

Effluent samples are first adjusted to pH 2 and then extracted with Diethyl Ether.  The extracts are rotary evaporated and the resulting residues, containing the Fatty Acids and other solvent soluble organics, are then redissolved in Methyl-t-butyl Ether (MTBE), transferred to small glass vials, methylated with Diazomethane, concentrated and cleaned up.  The extract is injected on a High Resolution Gas Chromatograph/Low Resolution Mass Spectrometer (HRGC/LRMS) system for analysis.  LRMS data is acquired in Total Ion Mode (TIM) and quantitation is performed using selected mass ions.  Positive identification of the various Fatty Acids is made on the basis of a comparison of absolute retention times to those of the external standards and computer based mass spectral mass/intensity library matching routines.

Positive identification of the various Fatty Acids is made on the basis of a comparison of absolute retention times to those of the external standards and computer based mass spectral mass/intensity library matching routines.

Low level Nitrate/Nitrite samples must be field filtered and collected in glass bottles with no dead space.  The filtered sample is passed through a column containing granulated copper-cadmium which reduces Nitrate to Nitrite.  Quantitative reduction is ensured by maintaining a stable H-ion concentration through addition of ammonium chloride (NH4Cl).  The Nitrite that is originally present in the sample plus the reduced Nitrate then react with sulphanilamide under acidic conditions to form a diazo compound.  This compound then complexes with N-1-naphthylethylenediamine dihydrochloride to form a reddish-purple azo dye, the absorbance of which is measured at 550 nm.  Nitrate (NO3) concentration can be calculated using the Nitrate & Nitrite result and subtracting the Nitrite result (NO23 - NO2 = NO3)

There is no acid digestion required for this analysis.  A water sample is collected and preserved in 0.2 percent nitric acid.  To analyse the extractable metals the sample is shaken, allowed to sit for at least twenty four hours, and a decanted portion is introduced to the spectrometer.  When the dissolved metals are required, the samples must first be filtered through a 0.45 micron cellulose acetate filter paper and then followed by preservation in 0.2 percent nitric acid.  It is important to note that different laboratories may have very different detection limits for some variables analyzed by ICP/MS.

This method provides an automated procedure for the Inductively Coupled Argon Plasma Optical Emission Spectrophotometric (ICP-OES) determination and quantitation of trace amounts of metals in surface, ground and precipitation waters after a manual acid digestion and concentration procedure and ultrasonic nebulisation.  Organically-bound metals and metal complexes are converted to metal ions by digestion with nitric acid [method details says HCl].  To increase the signal detected by the ICP, the samples are concentrated 10 times.  The liquid sample is pumped onto the piezoelectric transducer, where the ultrasonic action efficiently converts it to a fine, dense aerosol.  The nebulizer carrier gas flow then transports the wet aerosol through a heated U-tube, where the solvent is vaporized.  Subsequently, most of the solvent vapour is removed from the aerosol stream by passing the stream through a chilled condenser.  The result is a dry, analyte-laden aerosol which is introduced to the plasma.  There, the high temperature desolvates the aerosol and dissociates the sample material into individual atoms and ions, which are excited to emit light at wave lengths characteristic of the elements present.  Dissolved samples are field filtered through 0.45 micron cellulose acetate filter prior to acid preservation.  Samples for extractable analysis are acidified with 2 mL concentrated HNO3 per litre and allowed to stand a minimum of 24 hours before analysis.  Clients providing these samples are advised to preserve samples at the collection site.

Clients providing these samples are advised to preserve samples at the collection site.

This method provides an automated procedure for the Inductively Coupled Argon Plasma Optical Emission Spectrophotometric (ICP-OES) determination and quantitation of trace amounts of metals in surface, ground and precipitation waters after a manual acid digestion and concentration procedure and ultrasonic nebulisation.  Organically-bound metals and metal complexes are converted to metal ions by digestion with nitric acid [method details says HCl].  To increase the signal detected by the ICP, the samples are concentrated 10 times.  The liquid sample is pumped onto the piezoelectric transducer, where the ultrasonic action efficiently converts it to a fine, dense aerosol.  The nebulizer carrier gas flow then transports the wet aerosol through a heated U-tube, where the solvent is vaporized.  Subsequently, most of the solvent vapour is removed from the aerosol stream by passing the stream through a chilled condenser.  The result is a dry, analyte-laden aerosol which is introduced to the plasma.  There, the high temperature desolvates the aerosol and dissociates the sample material into individual atoms and ions, which are excited to emit light at wave lengths characteristic of the elements present.  Dissolved samples are field filtered through 0.45 micron cellulose acetate filter prior to acid preservation.  Samples for extractable analysis are acidified with 2 mL concentrated HNO3 per litre and allowed to stand a minimum of 24 hours before analysis.  Clients providing these samples are advised to preserve samples at the collection site.

There, the high temperature desolvates the aerosol and dissociates the sample material into individual atoms and ions, which are excited to emit light at wave lengths characteristic of the elements present.  Dissolved samples are field filtered through 0.45 micron cellulose acetate filter prior to acid preservation.  Samples for extractable analysis are acidified with 2 mL concentrated HNO3 per litre and allowed to stand a minimum of 24 hours before analysis.  Clients providing these samples are advised to preserve samples at the collection site.

This method provides an automated procedure for the Inductively Coupled Argon Plasma Optical Emission Spectrophotometric (ICP-OES) determination and quantitation of trace amounts of metals in surface, ground and precipitation waters after a manual acid digestion and concentration procedure and ultrasonic nebulisation.  Organically-bound metals and metal complexes are converted to metal ions by digestion with nitric acid.  To increase the signal detected by the ICP, the samples are concentrated 10 times.  The liquid sample is pumped onto the piezoelectric transducer, where the ultrasonic action efficiently converts it to a fine, dense aerosol.  The nebulizer carrier gas flow then transports the wet aerosol through a heated U-tube, where the solvent is vaporized.  Subsequently, most of the solvent vapour is removed from the aerosol stream by passing the stream through a chilled condenser.  The result is a dry, analyte-laden aerosol which is introduced to the plasma.  There, the high temperature desolvates the aerosol and dissociates the sample material into individual atoms and ions, which are excited to emit light at wave lengths characteristic of the elements present.  Dissolved samples are field filtered through 0.45 micron cellulose acetate filter prior to acid preservation.  Samples for extractable analysis are acidified with 2 mL concentrated HNO3 per litre and allowed to stand a minimum of 24 hours before analysis.  Clients providing these samples are advised to preserve samples at the collection site.

Effluent and water samples are acidified with Sulphuric Acid and extracted with Dichloromethane.  After concentration, the extract is methylated using ethereal Diazomethane.  Extracts are cleaned up as required using Florisil.  The extracts are analysed for Acid Extractable Herbicides using High Resolution Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture detection.  Positive results may be verified by use of a secondary confirmation GC column.

Samples are extracted with dichloromethane (DCM) in a separatory funnel.  Extracts are dried, concentrated and analyzed  by capillary gas chromatography with flame ionization detector.  Results are corrected for specified PAH concentrations.  LEPH is defined as the sum of components that elute on GC between nC10 and nC19; HEPH is defined as the sum of components that elute on gc between nC19 and nC32. Performance Base Method published circa Dec. 31, 2000, but distributed 1999.

Samples are dried and soxhlet extracted with dichloromethane (DCM) for 4 hours.  The extract is concentrated and analyzed by capillary gas chromatography with flame ionization detector.  Results are corrected for specified PAH concentrations and percent moisture.  LEPH is defined as the sum of components that elute on gc between nC1O and nC19; HEPH is defined as the sum of components that elute on gc between nC19 and nC32. Method superceded Dec. 2000.
