Samples are dried and soxhlet extracted with dichloromethane (DCM) for 4 hours.  The extract is concentrated and analyzed by capillary gas chromatography with flame ionization detector.  Results are corrected for percent moisture, but are not corrected for specified PAH's.  LEPH is defined as the sum of components that elute on gc between nC10 and nC19; HEPH is defined as the sum of components that elute on gc between nC19 and nC32. Method superceded Dec. 2000.

Samples are dried and soxhlet extracted with dichloromethane (DCM) for 4 hours.  The extract is concentrated and analyzed by capillary gas chromatography with flame ionization detector.  Results are corrected for percent moisture, but are not corrected for specified PAH's.  LEPH is defined as the sum of components that elute on gc between nC10 and nC19; HEPH is defined as the sum of components that elute on gc between nC19 and nC32. Method superceded Dec. 2000.

This method is applicable to determiniation of dissolved, extractable, and total recoverable metals in ground waters, surface waters, drinking waters, and wastewaters.  Dissolved, extractable, and total recoverable sample fractions are acidified to pH <1.5 with analytical grade nitric acid (HNO3) to prevent the metals from adsorbing to the container material or precipitating.  Extractable and total recoverable water samples are collected in 250 ml acid washed polyethylene bottles and are preserved with Nitric acid (0.5 ml acid for 100 mLs of sample).  All preserved samples are stored at room temperature and can be held for up to 6 months.  Unfiltered, un-preserved samples are stored at 4C for no more than 30 days.  For dissolved and extractable water fractions, no sample preparation is necessary.  Samples are simply poured in autosampler tubes (i.e. 15 ml centrifuge tubes), and placed on the autosampler and analyzed.  Samples for total recoverable metals are digested with Nitric acid in special Teflon tubes in an autoclave prior to analyses.

This method is applicable to determiniation of dissolved, extractable, and total recoverable metals in ground waters, surface waters, drinking waters, and wastewaters.  Dissolved, extractable, and total recoverable sample fractions are acidified to pH <1.5 with analytical grade nitric acid (HNO3) to prevent the metals from adsorbing to the container material or precipitating.  Extractable and total recoverable water samples are collected in 250 ml acid washed polyethylene bottles and are preserved with Nitric acid (0.5 ml acid for 100 mLs of sample).  All preserved samples are stored at room temperature and can be held for up to 6 months.  Unfiltered, un-preserved samples are stored at 4C for no more than 30 days.  For dissolved and extractable water fractions, no sample preparation is necessary.  Samples are simply poured in autosampler tubes (i.e. 15 ml centrifuge tubes), and placed on the autosampler and analyzed.  Samples for total recoverable metals are digested with Nitric acid in special Teflon tubes in an autoclave prior to analyses.

Dissolved, extractable, and total recoverable sample fractions are acidified to pH <1.5 with analytical grade nitric acid (HNO3) to prevent the metals from adsorbing to the container material or precipitating.  Extractable and total recoverable water samples are collected in 250 ml acid washed polyethylene bottles and are preserved with Nitric acid (0.5 ml acid for 100 mLs of sample).  All preserved samples are stored at room temperature and can be held for up to 6 months.  Unfiltered, un-preserved samples are stored at 4C for no more than 30 days.  For dissolved and extractable water fractions, no sample preparation is necessary.  Samples are simply poured in autosampler tubes (i.e. 15 ml centrifuge tubes), and placed on the autosampler and analyzed.  Samples for total recoverable metals are digested with Nitric acid in special Teflon tubes in an autoclave prior to analyses.

6.0 N Hydrochloric acid (HCI) is added to an aliquot of the sediment sample.  The extract produced from the addition of the acid is then analyzed for simultaneously extracted metals (SEM) using inductively coupled plasma - optical emission spectrophotometry.  The detection limits depend on the metal parameters in question and the instrumentation used.

25C Low Ionic Strength Electrode; measurements made at 25 +- .5 C.

An excess of Methyl-Orange reagent is added to a buffered sample forming a yellow complex which is subsequently extracted into Chloroform.  Standards, made using Cetyldimethylbenzylammonium Chloride (CDBAC), are extracted similarly.  The Absorbance of the Chloroform extracts is measured on a UV-VIS spectrophotometer at 415nm.  The concentration of CDBAC equivalents in the sample is determined by comparison of the sample Absorbance to that of the standards.  This method is a measure of cationic surfactants.

An approximately 225 uL of sample is introduced into an ion chromatograph (IC).  The anions of interest are separated and measured, using a system comprised of a guard column, analytical column, suppressor device, conductivity detector, a postcolumn reagent delivery system (pneumatically controlled), a heated postcolumn reaction coil, and an ultraviolet/visible (UV/VIS) absorbance detector.  They are identified on the basis of retention time as compared to standards.  Quantitation is by measurement of peak area against a calibration curve generated from known standards.

Volatile organic compounds (nC6-nC10) are purged from water samples with helium, adsorbed onto a sorbent trap, and then thermally desorbed to a capillary column gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector.
Observed Property ID: Surrogate standard used for F1(C6-C10) analysis. (ratio)

Method Description: Volatile organic compounds (nC6-nC10) are purged from water samples with helium, adsorbed onto a sorbent trap, and then thermally desorbed to a capillary column gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector.

Method Description: Wet solids samples are extracted with methanol using a mechanical shaker. Extracts are directly analyzed by a capillary column gas chromatography with flame ionization detection. Published as a Performance Based Method circa Dec. 2000.

Samples are dried and soxhlet extracted with 1: 1 Hexane: Acetone for 4 hours. The extract is concentrated and analyzed by capillary gas chromatography with flame ionization detector. Results are corrected for specified PAH concentrations. LEPH is defined as the sum of components that elute on gc between nC10 and nC19; HEPH is defined as the sum of components that elute on gc between nC19 and nC32. Performance Base Method published circa Dec. 31, 2000.

Volatile Petroleum Hydrocarbons (nC6 to nC10) are calculated using the results from selected methods. The calculation procedure for VPH requires that both Volatile Hydrocarbons (VH) and Monocyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (MAHs, including BTEX and styrene) be analyzed using methodologies which have been approved by the Director. Selected MAHs are subtracted from VH results to produce VPH values. The Procedure section lists the MAHs to be excluded from both waters and soils. Performance Based Method published circa Dec. 2000.

Effluent samples are acidified with Sulphuric Acid and extracted using C-18 Solid Phase Extraction (SPE) disks. Sterols are eluted with Acetone and concentrated. After concentration, the extract is acetylated using Pyridine and Acetic Anhydride.  A sterol Internal Standard is added and the extract is analysed using High Resolution Gas Chromatography/Low Resolution Mass Spectrometry (HRGC/LRMS). MS data is acquired in Selected Ion Mode (SIM) and quatitation is by multilevel Internal Standards.

A known quantity of the ambient air is filtered through a Pallflex Tissue Quartz Filter, or equivalent.  The maximum aerodynamic particle size, (PM10 or PM2.5) collected on the filter is determined during the sampling period.  A 47mm filter is cut from the original 8X10 filters.  Then digested in reverse aqua regia by microwave, and detection is by ICPMS.

Effluent and swab samples are extracted with hexane, the extract concentrated, and then treated using Florisil, concentrated Sulfuric Acid, activated Copper and Mercury (as required) to remove interferences.  The samples are then analysed using Megabore Column Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture Detection.  Oil samples are first diluted with Hexane then treated in the manner outlined for effluent and swab samples.  The samples are then analysed using Megabore Column Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture Detection.

Primary Reference - USEPA Method 549.1 "Determination of Diquat and Paraquat in Drinking Water by Liquid-Solid Extraction and HPLC-UV Detection".  Approximately 200mL of water is adjusted to pH 10.5.  Target organics are extracted using a prepared C18 solid sorbant cartridge by reverse phase/Ion Pair SPE.  Compounds are then extracted from the cartridge by eluting with an acidic aqueous solvent.  The eluate is injected into a HPLC for separation and quantification is achieved by measuring absorbance at 308nm for Diquat and 258nm for Paraquat.

Primary Reference - USEPA Method 549.1 "Determination of Diquat and Paraquat in Drinking Water by Liquid-Solid Extraction and HPLC-UV Detection".  Approximately 200mL of water is adjusted to pH 10.5.  Target organics are extracted using a prepared C18 solid sorbant cartridge by reverse phase/Ion Pair SPE.  Compounds are then extracted from the cartridge by eluting with an acidic aqueous solvent.  The eluate is injected into a HPLC for separation and quantification is achieved by measuring absorbance at 308nm for Diquat and 258nm for Paraquat.

Measurement of Nitrate is accomplished by the preparation of Nitrate standards in the range of 0-7mg/L-NO3-N.  Determination of sample nitrate concentration is accomplished by reading the UV absorbance of the sample at a wavelength at 220nm and at 275nm to determine interference.  A standard curve is constructed by plotting the absorbances due to NO3 conc. of standards.  Using the corrected sample absorbances, sample concentrations are obtained directly from the curve.

This procedure is used to estimate the amount of dissolved organic carbon (DOC) in waters and wastewaters. Some organic compounds regularly found in waters have strong UV absorptions. Thus there is a strong relationship between the UV absorption and the organic carbon content of the water. DOC is usually measured at 254nm, though other wavelengths are often chosen to minimize any interference in the sample. In this method an absorption scan of 250nm, 254nm, 310nm, 340nm, 360nm, and 365nm is read. In an average sample the absorption should decrease with the increase of the wavelength. However, irregularities in this trend could indicate some source of UV absorbing interference.

Total and Dissolved Inorganic Carbon by Automated Persulfate Colourimetric Method (TAACS 800 Industrial Method No. 860-87T, January 1989): The sample is mixed with phosphate buffer and persulphate in order to digest the inorganic compounds and convert them to CO2 Dialysis of the resultant CO2 through a gas-permeable silicone membrane to combine with a phenolphthalein solution causes a decrease on colour of the phenophthalein solution proportional to the original inorganic carbon concentration.  This colour change is measured at a wavelength of 550nm.

Total and Dissolved Inorganic Carbon by Automated Persulfate Colourimetric Method (TAACS 800 Industrial Method No. 860-87T, January 1989): The sample is mixed with phosphate buffer and persulphate in order to digest the inorganic compounds and convert them to CO2 Dialysis of the resultant CO2 through a gas-permeable silicone membrane to combine with a phenolphthalein solution causes a decrease on colour of the phenophthalein solution proportional to the original inorganic carbon concentration.  This colour change is measured at a wavelength of 550nm.

Phosphorus present in the sample is converted to soluble ortho-phosphate by digesting the sample with persulphate in an acidic medium.  The resulting ortho-phosphate then reacts with ammonium molybdate and antimony tartrate in an acidic medium to form an antimony-phosphomolybdate complex, which is reduced to an intensely blue coloured complex by ascorbic acid.  The absorbance of this complex is measured at 880 nm.

This analysis is based on the "Reference Method for the Canada-Wide Standard for Petroleum Hydrocarbons in Soil - Tier 1 Method, Canadian Council of Ministers of the Environment, December 2000."  For F1 (C6-C10), the sample undergoes a purge and trap extraction prior to analysis by GC/FID. The F1-BTEX result is calculated as follows: F1-BTEX: F1 (C6-C10) minus benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene and xylenes (BTEX).
CCME PHC in Soil - Tier 1

This analysis is based on the "Reference Method for the Canada-Wide Standard for Petroleum Hydrocarbons in Soil - Tier 1 Method, Canadian Council of Ministers of the Environment, December 2000."  For F1 (C6-C10), the sample undergoes a headspace purge prior to analysis by GC/FID. F1 (C6-C10): Sum of all hydrocarbons that elute between nC6 and nC10.

Effluents having salinity >10 ppt must be run with either Coho or Chinook suitably aclimated to appropriate salinity.  If  this bioassay is performed on lower salinity samples, all test tanks must be adjusted to similar salinity.

Rainbow/96hr(%mortality)/100% concentration.  (RM13) Biological Test Method: Reference Method for Determining Acute Lethality of Effluents to Rainbow Trout; EPS 1/RM/13 Second Edition December 2000 (with May 2007 and February 2016 amendments).  Rainbow Trout are exposed in a single concentration of the sample and mortality is recorded over a period of 96 hours at 15C. The pass/fail single concentration test uses undiluted material at 100% concentration and determines the percent mortality after 96 hours. (Without pH Adjustment)

This method measures the concentration (expressed as % weight/weight) at which 50% mortality occurs.  No pH adjustment usually is permitted.
This method measures the time (in hours) for which 50% mortality occurs in undiluted (i.e. 100% conc.) effluent.

Sample moisture is determined by weighing samples before and after freeze-drying.  Freeze-dried samples are ground in a Braun blender before being weighed into Teflon PFA liners and digested with concentrated HNO3, concentrated HCl, and 50% H2O2 in a microwave oven; which results in a complete sample dissolution.  Samples are cooled and volumized with Type I water.  Analysis is performed via Inductively Coupled Argon Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES) (simultaneous multielement analysis), Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (GF-AAS) (low level Cd and Pb analysis), Cold Vapor Atomic Fluorescence Spectrometry (CV-AFS) (Mercury analysis) and/or Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (F-AAS) (K analysis).

Sediment and homogenized biota samples are Acetone extracted using a wrist-action shaker, partitioned with 2% NaCl, then treated using Florisil, concentrated Sulfuric Acid, activated Copper and Mercury (as required) to remove interferences.  The samples are then analysed using Megabore Column Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture Detection.  Note that biota results are reported on a "wet weight" basis.

Freeze-dried samples are ground in a Braun blender before being weighed into Teflon PFA liners and digested with concentrated HNO3, concentrated HCl, and 50% H2O2 in a microwave oven; which results in a complete sample dissolution.  Samples are collected and volumized with Type I water.  Analysis is performed via Inductively Coupled Argon Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES) (simultaneous multielement analysis), Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (GF-AAS) (low level Cd and Pb analysis), Cold Vapor Atomic Fluorescence Spectrometry (CV-AFS) (Mercury analysis) and/or Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (F-AAS) (K analysis).

The Total Nitrogen present in the sample is oxidized to nitrate by digesting the sample with potassium persulphate in an alkaline medium.  The resulting Nitrate is reduced to Nitrite by passing it through a column containing granulated copper-cadmium.  The nitrite then reacts with sulfanilamide under acidic conditions to form a diazo compound.  This compound then complexes with N-1-naphthylethylenediamine dihydrochloride to form a reddish-purple azo dye, the absorbance of which is measured at 550 nm.

Sample moisture is determined by weighing samples before and after freeze-drying.  freeze-dried samples are ground in a Braun blender before being weighed into Teflon PFA liners and digested with concentrated HNO3, concentrated HCI, and 50% H2O2 in a microwave oven; which results in a complete sample dissolution.  Samples are collected and volumized with Type1 water.  Analysis is performed via Inductively Coupled Argon Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES) (simultaneous multielement analysis), Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption Spectometry (GF-AAS) (low leve Cd and Pb analysis), Cold Vapor Atomic Fluorescence Spectrometry (CV-AFS)(Mercury analysis) and/or Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (F-AAS) (K analysis).

Sample moisture is determined by weighing samples before and after freeze-drying.  Freeze-dried samples are ground in a Braun blender before being weighed into Teflon PFA liners and digested with concentrated nitric, concentrated hydrochloric and 30% hydrogen peroxide in a microwave oven; which results in a complete sample dissolution.  Samples are cooled and volumized with Type I water.  The digestion in a mixture of acids using microwave digestion techniques result in the complete extraction of selenium from tissues.  Analysis is performed via a graphite furnace atomic absorption (GFAA) technique, using Zeeman background correction system.  GFAA Spectroscopy involves heating the sample in 3 or more stages.  First, a low current heats the graphite tube to dry the sample.  The second, or charring stage, destroys organic matter and volatilizes other components at an intermediate temperature.  Finally, a high current heats the tube to incandescence and, in an inert atmosphere, atomizes the element being determined.  Additional stages may be added to aid in drying and charring, and to clean and cool the tube between samples.  The resultant ground-state atomic vapour absorbs monochromatic radiation from the source.  A photoelectric detector measures the intensity of transmitted radiation characteristic of the Se  or Sb absorption wavelength, which is inversely proportional to the quantity (concentration) of ground-state atoms in the optical path over a limited range.
Homogenized; hotplate HNO3 digestion; H2O2 digestion; CVAA

The method consisted of first spiking a portion of the undried tissue samples with an aliquot of three different surrogate standard solutions: one for the analysis of alkanes, aliphatics and linear alkylbenzenes in the F1 extract; one for the analysis of PAHs in the F2 extract; and one for alcohols and plant sterols in the F3.  Each tissue sample was ground with sodium sulphate, packed in a glass chromatographic column and eluted with methanol and dichloromethane.  The eluate was backwashed with extracted water.  The extract was concentrated and fractionated on silica gel into three fractions (F1, F2 and F3).  F1 and F3 extracts were concentrated and ampouled.  The F2 extract containing the PAH compounds of interest was washed with base to remove fatty acid interferences, concentrated and spiked with an aliquot of recovery standard solution prior to analysis by high resolution gas chromatography with low resolution (quadrupole) mass spectrometric detection (HRGC/LRMS).  Results reported on a wet weight basis.

Using the microplate technique and the Coulter Counter Model Z1, growth of the algae, S. capricornutum, exposed to the test substance is compared with algae growth in a control over a 72 hour time period. The 72 hour IC50 (the median inhibition concentration, i.e., the concentration estimated to cause a 50% reduction in growth compared to the control) or IC25 (the median inhibition concentration, i.e., the concentration estimated to cause a 25% reduction in growth compared to the control) is computed by comparing growth in the various test concentrations at the end of the test. Reference toxicant tests or positive controls are used to establish alga sensitivity.

Biota samples are extracted with Acetone, partitioned with 2% NaCl then back extracted with Hexane. The Hexane extract is then concentrated to small volume. The concentrated extracts are then treated using Florisil, concentrated Sulphuric Acid, activated Copper and/or Mercury (as required) to remove interferences. The samples are analysed using Microbore Column Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture Detection.

The chromium VI in the sample is reacted with diphenylcarbazide in an acid solution to produce a red-violet colour. The intensity of the colour is measured at 540 nm. Sample is lab or field filtered and preserved with NaOH.  This analysis is carried out using procedures adapted from method 3500-Cr C in "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" published by the American Public Health Association, and with procedures adapted from Method 1636 published by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The procedure involves analysis for chromium (VI) by ion chromatography using diphenylcarbazide in a sulphuric acid solution.

This analysis is carried out using procedures adapted from ASTM Method 7237 "Free Cyanide with Flow Injection Analysis (FIA) Utilizing Gas Diffusion Separation and Amperometric Detection".  Free cyanide is determined by in-line gas diffusion at pH 6 with final determination by colourimetric analysis.
Gas Diffusion (microdiffusion) ? Colourimetry based on EPA Method 9016 (Free Cyanide in Water, Soils and Solid Wastes by Microdiffusion)

APHA 3500-Fe B/James Ball et al (1999) This analysis is carried out using procedures adapted from APHA 3500-Fe B and "A New Method for the Direct Determination of Dissolved Iron Concentration in Acid Mine Waters" published by James W. Ball et al (1999). The procedure involves preliminary sample filtration, and ferrous iron is determined using the "FerroZine" colourimetric method.

Flame ionization capillary gas chromatography is the primary means used for determining and matching the type of hydrocarbons present.  Initial screening and all "high-boiling" hydrocarbons (those having a boiling range greater than or equal to diesel fuel) are analysed using a bonded-phase polymethyl/phenyl siloxane GC column.  All "low-boiling" hydrocarbons (those having a boiling range less than diesel fuel) are preferably analysed using a bonded-phase polymethyl siloxane GC column.  Identification is based on the recognition and matching of peak patterns in the chromatogram and comparison with those produced by "source" samples or commercial petroleum hydrocarbons standards.  The distribution and relative concentrations of the components are considered unique to a given oil.  The carbon range is determined by comparing the sample with a commercial "n-C5" to "n-C40" hydrocarbon calibration mix.  Infrared spectrophotometry (IR) is used to confirm a hydrocarbon sample as either a petroleum or vegetable-animal in origin.  The spectrum is examined for the presence or absence of a strong carbonyl absorption at about 1740 cm-1.  The absence of this peak is good evidence for a petroleum origin of the sample.  The spectrum can also be compared to that of other hydrocarbon standards.  Ultraviolet/Visible spectrophotometry (UV/Vis) is used to determine the theoretical ratio of the aromatic compounds containing 2 rings to those containing 3 or more rings.  Trace metals present in the sample are examined by ICP emission spectroscopy.  The Nickel-Vanadium ratio can be a good indicator when used for non-distillate petroleum hydrocarbons, however, "profile matching" of the concentrations of selected metals is generally more useful.  Note: Results from this test are non-numeric and therefore are reported in the comment field.

Samples are dried at 60 C, then either sieved to -100mesh (150 um) and rolled to homogenize, or finely ground with a mortar and pestle or a shatter box laboratory mill and rolled (depending on the submitter's requirements).  The samples are then weighed into Teflon digestion liners and digested with HNO3 and HCl in a microwave oven.  Samples are cooled, volumized, and allowed to settle overnight before being decanted.  Analysis is then performed via Inductively Coupled Argon Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES) (Simultaneous multi element analysis).
In ICP Spectrometry, the liquid sample is pumped to the nebulizer, where it is convertd into an aerosol. the nebulizer carrier gas flow than transports the wet aerosol past the impact bead, where the large droplets condense out and flow to the waste container.  The remaining fine aerosol is carried into the plasma.  There, the high temperature desolvates the aerosol and dissociates the sample material into individual atoms and ions, which are excited to emit light at wavelengths characteristic of the elements present.  A diffraction grating in the spectrometer diffracts the various wavelengths of light through exit slits to the photo-multiplier tubes, which convert the light energy to electronic signals.

There, the high temperature desolvates the aerosol and dissociates the sample material into individual atoms and ions, which are excited to emit light at wavelengths characteristic of the elements present.  A diffraction grating in the spectrometer diffracts the various wavelengths of light through exit slits to the photo-multiplier tubes, which convert the light energy to electronic signals.

Samples are dried at 60 C, then either sieved to -100mesh (150 um) and rolled to homogenize, or finely ground with a mortar and pestle or a shatter box laboratory mill and rolled (depending on the submitter's requirements).  The samples are then weighed into Teflon digestion liners and digested with HNO3 and HCl in a microwave oven.  Samples are cooled, volumized, and allowed to settle overnight before being decanted.  Analysis is then performed via Inductively Coupled Argon Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES) (Simultaneous multi element analysis).

In ICP Spectrometry, the liquid sample is pumped to the nebulizer, where it is convertd into an aerosol. the nebulizer carrier gas flow than transports the wet aerosol past the impact bead, where the large droplets condense out and flow to the waste container. Samples are dried at 60 C, then either sieved to -100 mesh (150 um) and rolled to homogenize, or finely ground with a mortar and pestle or a shatter box laboratory mill and rolled (depending on the submitter's requirements).  The samples are then weighed into Teflon digestion liners and digested with HNO3 and HCl in a microwave oven.  Samples are cooled, volumized, and allowed to settle overnight before being decanted.  Analysis is then performed via Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (GF-AAS) (low level analysis).
GFAA Spectrometry involves heating the sample in three or more stages.  First, a low current heats the graphite tube to dry the sample.  The second, or charring stage, destroys the organic matter and volatilizes other components at an intermediate temperature.  Finally, a high current heats the tube to incandescence and, in an inert atmosphere, atomizes the element being determined.  Additional stages may be added to drying and charring, and to cool and clean the tubes in between samples.  The resultant ground-state atomic vapour absorbs monochromatic radiation from the source.  A photoelectric detector measures the intensity of the transmitted radiation characteristic of the element being determined, which is inversely proportional to the concentration of ground-state atoms in the optical path over a limited range.  Low level Cadmium and Lead are determined using Deuterium lamp background correction system whereas Arsenic and Selenium are determined by using Zeeman background correction system.

The second, or charring stage, destroys the organic matter and volatilizes other components at an intermediate temperature.  Finally, a high current heats the tube to incandescence and, in an inert atmosphere, atomizes the element being determined.  Additional stages may be added to drying and charring, and to cool and clean the tubes in between samples.  The resultant ground-state atomic vapour absorbs monochromatic radiation from the source.  A photoelectric detector measures the intensity of the transmitted radiation characteristic of the element being determined, which is inversely proportional to the concentration of ground-state atoms in the optical path over a limited range.  Low level Cadmium and Lead are determined using Deuterium lamp background correction system whereas Arsenic and Selenium are determined by using Zeeman background correction system.

Static Headspace anaylsis is a method for the determination of volatile compounds in liquids and/or solids by analysing the vapour phase of a sample in a closed system; in this case a sealed vial.  Static Headspace is sometimes referred to as Equilibrium Headspace because the vapour phase above the sample in a sealed vial is brought into thermodynamic equilibrium with the sample prior to analysis.  Volatile organic compounds are thermally extracted from the sample matrix by Static Headspace sampling and introduced directly to a thick-film megabore GC column.  Compounds eluting from the GC column are introduced into a Mass Spectrometer and target compounds are identified by a comparison of both retention times and mass spectra with those of reference standards stored in a computerized data system.  Reference retention times and mass spectra for analytes are obtained by the measurement of calibration standards under precisely the same extraction conditions used for samples.  The concentration of each identified component is measured by relating the response of the sample quantitation mass ions to the response of the quantitation mass ions of a series of external standards.  A deuterated surrogate recovery standard is added to provide information on matrix effects.

Static Headspace is sometimes referred to as Equilibrium Headspace because the vapour phase above the sample in a sealed vial is brought into thermodynamic equilibrium with the sample prior to analysis.  Volatile organic compounds are thermally extracted from the sample matrix by Static Headspace sampling and introduced directly to a thick-film megabore GC column.  Compounds eluting from the GC column are introduced into a Mass Spectrometer and target compounds are identified by a comparison of both retention times and mass spectra with those of reference standards stored in a computerized data system.  Reference retention times and mass spectra for analytes are obtained by the measurement of calibration standards under precisely the same extraction conditions used for samples.  The concentration of each identified component is measured by relating the response of the sample quantitation mass ions to the response of the quantitation mass ions of a series of external standards.  A deuterated surrogate recovery standard is added to provide information on matrix effects.

Sediment samples are extracted by shaking with Methanol in a screw cap centrifuge bottle.  The extracts are rotary evaporated and the resulting residues, containing the Resin Acids and other solvent soluble organics, are then redissolved in Methanol, transferred to small glass vials, methylated with Diazomethane then evaporated to dryness under Nitrogen.  [Methylation Reaction  R-COOH(Resin/Fatty Acids) + CH2N2 (Diazomethane) = R-COOCH3 (Methyl ester) + N2]  The residue is re-dissolved in Methyl t-Butyl Ether (MTBE) and injected on a High Resolution Gas Chromatograph / Low Resolution Mass Spectrometer (HRGC/LRMS) system for analysis.  LRMS data is acquired in Total Ion Mode (TIM) and quantitation is performed using selected mass ions.  Positive identification of the various Resin Acids is made on the basis of a comparison of absolute retention times to those of the external standards and computer based mass spectral mass/intensity library matching routines.

Sediment and homogenized biota samples are Acetone extracted using a wrist-action shaker, partitioned with 2% NaCl, then treated using Florisil, concentrated Sulfuric Acid, activated Copper and Mercury (as required) to remove interferences.  The samples are then analysed using Megabore Column Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture Detection.

Freon 113 soluble compounds are extracted from an acidified effluent sample and made up to a measured volume.  Sediment samples are acidified then extracted using a wrist-action shaker.  The "Oils and Greases" content of the Freon extracts is determined using an Infrared Spectrophotometer with commercial quantitation software.  Quantitation is based on the comparison of the Absorbance difference between samples and a synthetic oil standard.  As there is no sample Absorbance band at 4000 cm-1 it represents a useful reference value to compensate for minor differences between spectrophotometer quartz cells.  Sample Absorbance at 2935 cm-1 represents the C-H stretching frequency of the aliphatic hydrocarbons of which typical environmental "Oils and Greases" are comprised.  "Hydrocarbons" are quantitated in the same manner after treating the Freon 113 extract with Silica Gel.

Freon 113 soluble compounds are extracted from an acidified effluent sample and made up to a measured volume.  Sediment samples are acidified then extracted using a wrist-action shaker.  The "Oils and Greases" content of the Freon extracts is determined using an Infrared Spectrophotometer with commercial quantitation software.  Quantitation is based on the comparison of the Absorbance difference between samples and a synthetic oil standard.  As there is no sample Absorbance band at 4000 cm-1 it represents a useful reference value to compensate for minor differences between spectrophotometer quartz cells.  Sample Absorbance at 2935 cm-1 represents the C-H stretching frequency of the aliphatic hydrocarbons of which typical environmental "Oils and Greases" are comprised.  "Hydrocarbons" are quantitated in the same manner after treating the Freon 113 extract with Silica Gel.

Samples are dried at 60 C, then either sieved to -100 mesh (150 um) and rolled to homogenize, or finely ground with a mortar and pestle or a shatter box laboratory mill and rolled (depending on the submitter's requirements).  The samples are then weighed into Teflon digestion liners and digested with HNO3 and HCI in a microwave oven.  Samples are cooled, volumized, and allowed to settle overnight before being decanted.  Anaysis is then performed via Inductively Coupled Argon Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES) (Simultaneous multi element analysis), Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption spectrometry (GF-AAS)(low level analysis), Cold Vapor Atomic Fluorescence Spectrometry (CV-AFS) (Mercury analysis) and/or Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (F-AAS)(K analysis).

The Total Nitrogen present in the sample is oxidized to nitrate by digesting the sample with potassium persulphate in an alkaline medium.  The resulting Nitrate is reduced to Nitrite by passing it through a column containing granulated copper-cadmium.  The nitrite then reacts with sulfanilamide under acidic conditions to form a diazo compound.  This compound then complexes with N-1-naphthylethylenediamine dihydrochloride to form a reddish-purple azo dye, the absorbance of which is measured at 550 nm.

Sediment and homogenized biota samples are Acetone extracted using a wrist-action shaker, Hexane partitioned using a Sodium Chloride solution, then treated in the manner outlined for effluent samples.  The extracts are analysed using megabore column Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture Detection.

Sediment and homogenized biota samples to be analysed for Chlorinated Phenols are Acetone extracted using a wrist-action shaker, partitioned with 2% NaCl and Hexane, methylated, then cleaned up and analysed in the manner outlined for effluent samples.  Sediment and homogenized biota samples to be analysed for Chlorinated Anisoles are Acetone extracted using a wrist-action shaker, partitioned with 2% NaCl and Hexane, then cleaned up and analysed in the manner outlined for effluent samples.  The extracts are analysed for Chlorinated Anisoles and/or Chlorinated Phenols using High Resolution Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture detection.

For weak acid dissociable cyanide, CN(WAD), the solid sample is added to type one water and is refluxed for 1 hour in the presence of Zinc acetate and sodium acetate.  The HCN is liberated from this slightly acidified (pH 4.5 - 6.0) sample.  The acetate buffer used contains Zinc salts to precipitate iron cyanide as a further assurance of the selectivity of the method.  For strong acid dissociable cyanide, CN(SAD), the solid sample is added to Type 1 water and is refluxed for 1 hour in the presence of sulphuric acid and magnesium chloride.  For both CN(WAD) and CN(SAD) the HCN generated reacts instantaneously with nickel ions in an ammoniacal solution to form the ionic tetracyanonickelate (II) anion complex, Ni (CN)4-2, which has a characteristic ultra-violet spectrum, and is measured at 267 and 284 nm.

Sediment samples are shaken with a mixture of Dichloromethane, Methanol and Sulphuric Acid, filtered, then extracted with Dichloromethane.  After concentration, the extract is methylated using ethereal Diazomethane.  Extracts are cleaned up as required using Florisil.  The extracts are analysed for Acid Extractable Herbicides using High Resolution Gas Chromatography with Electron Capture detection.  Positive results may be verified by use of a secondary confirmation GC column.

Hydrochloric acid, 6.0 N HCI, is added to the air-dried sediment samples.  The hydrogen sulfide (H2S) produced is carried into two sodium hydroxide (NaOH) sulfide traps by purified nitrogen gas.  The acid volatile sulfide absorbed in the NaOH is then determined colourimetrically.  The detection limit is 0.2 umol/g.

The method consisted of first spiking a portion of the undried sediment samples with an aliquot of three different surrogate standard solutions: one for the analysis of alkanes, aliphatics and linear alkylbenzenes in the F1 extract; one for the analysis of PAHs in the F2 extract; and one for alcohols and plant sterols in the F3.  Each tissue sample was ground with sodium sulphate, packed in a glass chromatographic column and eluted with methanol and dichloromethane.  The eluate was backwashed with extracted water.  The extract was concentrated and fractionated on silica gel into three fractions (F1, F2 and F3).  F1 and F3 extracts were concentrated and ampouled.  The F2 extract containing the PAH compounds of interest was washed with base to remove fatty acid interferences, concentrated and spiked with an aliquot of recovery standard solution prior to analysis by high resolution gas chromatography with low resolution (quadrupole) mass spectrometric detection (HRGC/LRMS).  Results reported on a dry weight basis, based on moisture analysis of a separate aliquot.

Sulfide ion is measured potentiometrically using a sulfide ion-selective electrode in conjuction with a double-junction, sleeve type reference electrode.  Potentials are read using a pH metre having an expanded millivolt scale capable of being read to the nearest 0.1 mV.  Samples are treated prior to analysis with sulfide anti-oxidant buffer (SAOB).  This buffer fixes the solution pH at a highly alkaline level, and contains ascorbic acid to retard air oxidation of sulfide ion in solution.  This ensures that sulfide present occurs chiefly as S= ion rather than as complexed HS- or H2S which are present at lower pH values.  The sulfide ion concentration is measured indirectly by observing the silver ion activity in the sample.  (Because of the extreme insolubility of silver sulfide, if either ion is present in a solution the other is absent.)  A minute quantity of silver ions is released to the sample from the solid silver sulfide membrane of the electrode.  These ions set up a potential with the silver ions in the internal reference solution.  The silver ion activity in the sample is dependent on the sulfide ion activity in the sample.  The relationships of the two ion activities is: E = Eb - 2.3* RT/nF* log As  (where E=measured total potential of the system; Eb=the portion of the total potential due to the reference electrode and its filling solution; As=the activity of the sulfide ion in the sample; 2.3* RT/nF=Nernst factor)  The potential (E) for each standard is plotted linearly against concentration on a log scale to produce a standard curve.

Total Carbon is determined by high temperature oxidation of carbon to carbon diooxide which is then measured by means of a nondispersive infrared analyzer.  Inorganic Carbon is determined by reaction with phosphoric acid to convert all carbonates to carbon dioxide which is also measured by  means of a nondispersive infrared analyzer.  Total Organic Carbon is determined as the difference between Total and Inorganic Carbons.

Method Name: Glycols in Soil and Water by GC/FID
Method Description: GLYCOLS IN SOIL AND WATER PURPOSE/PRINCIPLE OF METHOD: Soils are extracted with water and liquids are injected directly or diluted with water. The final extract is analyzed by direct injection gas chromatography with a flame ionization detector (GC/FID) due to the high solubility of glycols.  SCOPE: Glycols are commonly used for many applications such as a de-icing agent in aircraft and runway, as an anti-freeze in heating and cooling systems, as an industrial solvent, and in paint and plastics. The end data is used for various purposes including contamination assessment, environmental regulatory compliance and land reclamation. REFERENCES: Nonhalogenated Organics Using GC/FID. US EPA. Test Methods for Evaluating Solid Waste, Physical/Chemical Methods -- SW-846, Method 8015B Revision 2, December 1996

Method Description: xml:space="preserve">ALS Minerals S-GRA07.  Carbon disulfide is added to a prepared sample and the mixture is shaken for 30 minutes. An aliquot of the solution is taken and evaporated until dry.  The residue is then weighed as elemental sulfur.
This method is a catch-all for gravimetric procedures with units in percent.

xml:space="preserve">ALS Minerals OA-GRA05.  The determination of the mass loss from solid combustion residues upon heating in an air or oxygen atmosphere to a prescribed temperature. The mass loss can be due to the loss of moisture; carbon; sulfur; and so forth; from the decomposition or combustion of the residue.

Method Name: Gravimetric: balance: Separation by sieve >.075 mm
Method Description: Gravimetric, balance; Separation by sieve >.075 mm.  These are particle sizing determinations performed on soil.  These two parameters reported will need the > and < associated with them because the way they have been reported is not based on a number of distinct and specific sieve sizes but instead more general size of everything that is either larger or greater than a size of 0.075mm.

Method Name: Metals in Soil by CRC ICPMS
Method Description: This analysis is carried out using procedures from CSR Analytical Method: "Strong Acid Leachable Metals (SALM) in Soil", BC Ministry of Environment, 26 June 2009, and procedures adapted from EPA Method 200.2.  The sample is manually homogenized, dried at 60 degrees Celsius, sieved through a 63 um (230 mesh)  sieve, and a representative subsample of the dry material is weighed.  The sample is then digested at 95 degrees Celsius for 2 hours by block digester using concentrated nitric and hydrochloric acids.  Instrumental analysis is by collision cell inductively coupled plasma - mass spectrometry (modifed from EPA Method 6020A). Method Limitation: This method is not a total digestion technique.  It is a very strong acid digestion that is intended to dissolve those metals that may be environmentally available.  By design, elements bound in silicate structures are not normally dissolved by this procedure as they are not usually mobile in the environment.

ALS Minerals C-IR06.  Sample is treated with 50% HCl and heated for 5 mins at 125C to expel carbonates as CO2. The remaining solution is vacuum filtered through a filtering crucible, and the residue is analysed via induction furnace and infrared spectroscopy.

xml:space="preserve">ALS Minerals C-IR07.  Sample is heated to 1350C in an induction furnace with oxygen stream. Carbon dioxide released from the sample are measured by an IR detection system (Leco analyzer).
ALS Minerals C-IR07/C-IR17.  Total inorganic carbon is calculated by difference from total carbon (C-IR07) minus total organic carbon (C-IR17).

ALS Minerals ME-IR08.  A prepared sample is heated to approximately 1350C in an induction furnace with oxygen stream. Sulfur and carbon dioxide released from the sample are measured by IR (Leco analyzer)

ALS Minerals ME-IR08.  A prepared sample is heated to approximately 1350C in an induction furnace with oxygen stream. Sulfur and carbon dioxide released from the sample are measured by IR (Leco analyzer)

xml:space="preserve">ALS Minerals C-IR17.  Sample is heated at 105C with 50% HCl added dropwise to evolve inorganic carbonates as CO2. The process repeated several times; after which the residue is dried and washed with deionized water to remove the remaining acid and stop the reaction. The remainder of the sample; taken to be non-carbonate carbon, is analysed by induction furnace and infrared spectroscopy.
Isotope-ratio Mass Spectrometry (IRMS)
Isotope-ratio Mass Spectrometry (IRMS)

If the sample is not clear, filter a portion of the sample using a RC filter. An aliquot of the sample is taken and internal standard is added. The sample is analyzed by LC/MS/MS based on EPA Method 549.2 (LC-UV) (Determination of Diquat and Paraquat in Drinking Water by Liquid-Solid Extraction and High-Performance Liquid Chromatography with Ultraviolet Detection)

If the sample is not clear, filter a portion of the sample using a RC filter. An aliquot of the sample is taken and internal standard is added. The sample is analyzed by LC/MS/MS based on EPA Method 549.2 (LC-UV) (Determination of Diquat and Paraquat in Drinking Water by Liquid-Solid Extraction and High-Performance Liquid Chromatography with Ultraviolet Detection)
Indophenol Colourimetric Method 401 CTM027

Dissolved and extractable water samples are ready for analysis once collected.  Total samples are autoclaved with HNO3 and hydrochloric acid (HCl) in capped Teflon vials.  Analysis is performed via Inductively Coupled Argon Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES) (simultaneous multielement analysis), Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (GF-AAS) (low level analysis) and/or Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (F-AAS).  Total Hardness is calculated from the dissolved (or extractable as a substitute) fractions of Ca, Mg, Sr, Fe, Al, Zn, Mn, Cu, Ba, Pb, according to the following formula: Hardness Total = 2.497248*Ca + 4.116885*Mg + 1.142316*Sr + 1.792213*Fe + 3.709568*Al + 1.531126*Zn + 1.821866*Mn + 1.575224*Cu + 0.728773*Ba + 0.483082*Pb (where Total Hardness is expressed as mg/L of CaCO3, and each element is expressed in mg/L.  Check Media/Pres. codes for consistency with regard to acid preservation.

Method Name: Methane: Ethane and Ethene: Dissolved via GC-FID
Method Description: Water samples are collected in 44 mL P&T vials without headspace and preserved with Sodium Bisulfate.  Headspace is then generated using Nitrogen. The sample is then shaken to allow gas equilibration.   A portion of the headspace vapour is withdrawn and injected into a gas chromatograph equipped with capillary columns and a flame ionization detector (FID). The concentration of the gas in the liquid is proportional to the partial pressure of the gas above the liquid, and is calculated using Henrys Law.  Ref: EPA REGION 1, NATATTEN.WPD, REV. 1

MEND (mod) EPA 300.1 (mod). Inorganic anions are analyzed by obtaining an extract from a soil sample that has been added in a 3: 1 ratio of deionized water to soil; then leached and the extract filtered prior to analysis; which is then analyzed by Ion Chromatography with conductivity and/or UV detection.

Ultra trace metals in water are analyzed by CRC ICPMS, based on US EPA Method 6020B (July 2014). This procedure is intended for pristine field-filtered acid-preserved water samples.  The detection limits (LOR) for this test are based on lab instrumental analysis only, not including filtration. ALS-supplied field filtration equipment does not support these LOR. Therefore, because of the high probability of false positives due to filtration, it is strongly recommended that a filtration blank be analysed to aid in data interpretation. BC Ministry of Environment version.

Therefore, because of the high probability of false positives due to filtration, it is strongly recommended that a filtration blank be analysed to aid in data interpretation.

The detection limits (LOR) for this test are based on lab instrumental analysis only, not including filtration. ALS-supplied field filtration equipment does not support these LOR. Therefore, because of the high probability of false positives due to filtration, it is strongly recommended that a filtration blank be analysed to aid in data interpretation.

Ultra trace metals in water are analyzed by CRC ICPMS, based on US EPA Method 6020B (July 2014).  The detection limits provided can only be met for undigested samples.  This procedure is intended for colorless, non-turbid, acid-preserved water samples (i.e. pristine water samples), having turbidity < 1 NTU and no odor.  Where turbidity exceeds 1 NTU, and/or the sample is colored and has an odor, results may be biased low compared to true Total Metals concentrations.  ALS recommends that turbidity analysis be requested on samples submitted for this test to aid with interpretation of results. Where turbidity is <1NTU, undigested metals are equivalent to total metals concentrations.

Ultra trace metals in water are analyzed by CRC ICPMS, based on US EPA Method 6020B (July 2014).  The detection limits provided can only be met for undigested samples.  This procedure is intended for colorless, non-turbid, acid-preserved water samples (i.e. pristine water samples), having turbidity < 1 NTU and no odor.  Where turbidity exceeds 1 NTU, and/or the sample is colored and has an odor, results may be biased low compared to true Total Metals concentrations.  ALS recommends that turbidity analysis be requested on samples submitted for this test to aid with interpretation of results. Where turbidity is <1NTU, undigested metals are equivalent to total metals concentrations. BC Ministry of Environment version.

Ultra trace metals in water are analyzed by CRC ICPMS, based on US EPA Method 6020B (July 2014).  The detection limits provided can only be met for undigested samples.  This procedure is intended for colorless, non-turbid, acid-preserved water samples (i.e. pristine water samples), having turbidity < 1 NTU and no odor.  Where turbidity exceeds 1 NTU, and/or the sample is colored and has an odor, results may be biased low compared to true Total Metals concentrations.  ALS recommends that turbidity analysis be requested on samples submitted for this test to aid with interpretation of results. Where turbidity is <1NTU, undigested metals are equivalent to total metals concentrations. BC Ministry of Environment version.

Ultra trace metals in water are analyzed by CRC ICPMS, based on US EPA Method 6020B (July 2014).  The detection limits provided can only be met for undigested samples.  This procedure is intended for colorless, non-turbid, acid-preserved water samples (i.e. pristine water samples), having turbidity < 1 NTU and no odor.  Where turbidity exceeds 1 NTU, and/or the sample is colored and has an odor, results may be biased low compared to true Total Metals concentrations. Where turbidity is <1NTU, undigested metals are equivalent to total metals concentrations. BC Ministry of Environment version.

(Water) A static headspace procedure is used as a means of driving the analytes out of the matrix into a headspace.  Once equilibrium is achieved, a fixed volume of headspeace is taken for subsequent determination by Gas Chromatography - Mass Spectroscopy (GC/MS) using Selected Ion Monitoring.

xml:space="preserve">ALS Minerals: ME-MS81.  A prepared sample (0.100 g) is added to lithium metaborate/lithium tetraborate flux; mixed well and fused in a furnace at 1025C. The resulting melt is then cooled and dissolved in an acid mixture containing nitric; hydrochloric and hydrofluoric acids. This solution is then analyzed by inductively coupled plasma - mass spectrometry.

This method describes the multi-elemental determination of trace elements by Collision/Reaction Cell (CRC) ICP-MS. The method measures ions produced by a radio-frequency inductively coupled plasma. Analyte species originating in a liquid are pneumatically nebulized and the resulting aerosol transported by argon gas into the plasma torch. The ions produced are entrained in the plasma gas and extracted, by means of a differentially pumped vacuum interface, into a mass spectrometer. The ions flow through a Collision/Reaction Cell (CRC) where depending on the mode of analysis either the ions passes through the cell unhindered (no gas - classical ICP-MS mode), or collisions/reactions chemistry takes place between the ions and a neutral gas such as hydrogen or helium. Any polyatomic ions which give interference on the analytes are removed. The ions are then sorted according to their mass-to-charge ratios by a quadrupole mass spectrometer. The ions are then sorted according to their mass-to-charge ratios by a quadrupole mass spectrometer. The ions transmitted through the quadrupole are quantified by a channel electron multiplier and the ion information processed by a data handling system. Although most polyatomic interference is removed, any additional interference must be assessed and valid corrections applied or the data flagged to indicate problems. Interference correction must include compensation for background ions contributed by the plasma gas, reagents, and constituents of the sample matrix. Instrument drift as well as suppressions or enhancements of instrument response caused by the sample matrix must be corrected for by the use of internal standards.

This method describes the multi-elemental determination of trace elements by Collision/Reaction Cell (CRC) ICP-MS. The method measures ions produced by a radio-frequency inductively coupled plasma. Analyte species originating in a liquid are pneumatically nebulized and the resulting aerosol transported by argon gas into the plasma torch. The ions produced are entrained in the plasma gas and extracted, by means of a differentially pumped vacuum interface, into a mass spectrometer. The ions flow through a Collision/Reaction Cell (CRC) where depending on the mode of analysis either the ions passes through the cell unhindered (no gas - classical ICP-MS mode), or collisions/reactions chemistry takes place between the ions and a neutral gas such as hydrogen or helium. Any polyatomic ions which give interference on the analytes are removed. The ions are then sorted according to their mass-to-charge ratios by a quadrupole mass spectrometer. The ions are then sorted according to their mass-to-charge ratios by a quadrupole mass spectrometer. The ions transmitted through the quadrupole are quantified by a channel electron multiplier and the ion information processed by a data handling system. Although most polyatomic interference is removed, any additional interference must be assessed and valid corrections applied or the data flagged to indicate problems. Interference correction must include compensation for background ions contributed by the plasma gas, reagents, and constituents of the sample matrix. Instrument drift as well as suppressions or enhancements of instrument response caused by the sample matrix must be corrected for by the use of internal standards.

This method describes the multi-elemental determination of trace elements by Collision/Reaction Cell (CRC) ICP-MS. The method measures ions produced by a radio-frequency inductively coupled plasma. Analyte species originating in a liquid are pneumatically nebulized and the resulting aerosol transported by argon gas into the plasma torch. The ions produced are entrained in the plasma gas and extracted, by means of a differentially pumped vacuum interface, into a mass spectrometer. The ions flow through a Collision/Reaction Cell (CRC) where depending on the mode of analysis either the ions passes through the cell unhindered (no gas - classical ICP-MS mode), or collisions/reactions chemistry takes place between the ions and a neutral gas such as hydrogen or helium. Any polyatomic ions which give interference on the analytes are removed. The ions are then sorted according to their mass-to-charge ratios by a quadrupole mass spectrometer. The ions are then sorted according to their mass-to-charge ratios by a quadrupole mass spectrometer. The ions transmitted through the quadrupole are quantified by a channel electron multiplier and the ion information processed by a data handling system. Although most polyatomic interference is removed, any additional interference must be assessed and valid corrections applied or the data flagged to indicate problems. Interference correction must include compensation for background ions contributed by the plasma gas, reagents, and constituents of the sample matrix. Instrument drift as well as suppressions or enhancements of instrument response caused by the sample matrix must be corrected for by the use of internal standards.

This method describes the multi-elemental determination of trace elements by Collision/Reaction Cell (CRC) ICP-MS. The method measures ions produced by a radio-frequency inductively coupled plasma. Analyte species originating in a liquid are pneumatically nebulized and the resulting aerosol transported by argon gas into the plasma torch. The ions produced are entrained in the plasma gas and extracted, by means of a differentially pumped vacuum interface, into a mass spectrometer. The ions flow through a Collision/Reaction Cell (CRC) where depending on the mode of analysis either the ions passes through the cell unhindered (no gas - classical ICP-MS mode), or collisions/reactions chemistry takes place between the ions and a neutral gas such as hydrogen or helium. Any polyatomic ions which give interference on the analytes are removed. The ions are then sorted according to their mass-to-charge ratios by a quadrupole mass spectrometer. The ions are then sorted according to their mass-to-charge ratios by a quadrupole mass spectrometer. The ions transmitted through the quadrupole are quantified by a channel electron multiplier and the ion information processed by a data handling system. Although most polyatomic interference is removed, any additional interference must be assessed and valid corrections applied or the data flagged to indicate problems. Interference correction must include compensation for background ions contributed by the plasma gas, reagents, and constituents of the sample matrix. Instrument drift as well as suppressions or enhancements of instrument response caused by the sample matrix must be corrected for by the use of internal standards.

Metals in Tissue by CRC ICPMS (DRY)             Methodology: This method is conducted following British Columbia Lab Manual method "Metals in Animal Tissue and Vegetation (Biota) - Prescriptive". Tissue samples are homogenized and sub-sampled prior to hotblock digestion with nitric and hydrochloric acids, in combination with addition of hydrogen peroxide.  Instrumental analysis is by collision cell inductively coupled plasma - mass spectrometry (modified from EPA Method 6020A).  Method Limitation: This method employs a strong acid/peroxide digestion, and is intended to provide a conservative estimate of bio-available metals.  Near complete recoveries are achieved for most toxicologically important metals, but elements associated with recalcitrant minerals may be only partially recovered.

Instrumental analysis is by collision cell inductively coupled plasma - mass spectrometry (modified from EPA Method 6020A).  Method Limitation: This method employs a strong acid/peroxide digestion, and is intended to provide a conservative estimate of bio-available metals.  Near complete recoveries are achieved for most toxicologically important metals, but elements associated with recalcitrant minerals may be only partially recovered.

This analysis is carried out using procedures adapted from "Test Methods for Evaluating Solid Waste" SW-846, Methods 3510, 3630, 3660 and 8081, published by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The procedure involves extraction of the entire water sample with dichloromethane. The extract then undergoes one or more of the following clean-up procedures (if required): silica gel clean-up and/or sulphur clean-up. The final extract is analyzed by dual capillary column gas chromatography with electron capture detection (GC/ECD).

To determine the quantity of combustible Total Nitrogen in water, the aqueous sample is injected into a combustion furnace with a temperature of greater than 700oC (with a catalyst).  The nitrogen is converted to NO.  The carrier gas sweeps the NO to the nitrogen module where NO is mixed with ozone and then forms NO2 in its excited state.  When NO2 in its excited state returns to ground state, extra energy is given off as light.  This phenomenon is called chemiluminescence.  This light is then quantified using a chemiluminescence detector that is attached to the Apollo 9000 HS instrument.
Ammonia in Water by Fluorescence
Ammonia in Water by Fluorescence

A fluorescent derivative is formed by reacting ortho-phthaldialdehyde (OPA) and sulphite with ammonium. A sample is injected in a matrix matched carrier which is then mixed with a sodium hydroxide solution to convert the free ammonium into ammonia gas. After mixing, this basic solution is pushed through a dialysis PTFE membrane to the receiver OPA solution which then reacts to form the fluorescent derivative. This reaction is further increased (Intensified) by passing through a 62 degree inline reaction loop which then is detected and quantified using an inline fluorescent detector. This method is applicable for the measurement of ammonium in drinking water, ground water, and can be acceptable for brackish waters.

A fluorescent derivative is formed by reacting ortho-phthaldialdehyde (OPA) and sulphite with ammonium. A sample is injected in a matrix matched carrier which is then mixed with a sodium hydroxide solution to convert the free ammonium into ammonia gas. After mixing, this basic solution is pushed through a dialysis PTFE membrane to the receiver OPA solution which then reacts to form the fluorescent derivative. This reaction is further increased (Intensified) by passing through a 62 degree inline reaction loop which then is detected and quantified using an inline fluorescent detector. This method is applicable for the measurement of ammonium in drinking water, ground water, and can be acceptable for brackish waters.

This analysis is carried out in accordance with the procedure described in the "ASTM" method D1498-00 "Oxidation-Reduction Potential of Water" published by the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM), May 2000.  Results are reported as observed oxidation-reduction potential of the platinum metal-reference electrode employed, in mV.
Org. Special Analysis

An acidified water sample is extracted with dichloromethane.  The raw extract is concentrated and the phenols and acids are reacted with diazomethane, or other suitable derivatizing agent, to produce the corresponding derivatives.  If required, the extracts are subjected to Florisil column chromatography and divided into different fractions.  The derivatives are analyzed by electron capture gas liquid chromatography.

The water sample is acidified and extracted with dichloro-methane.  The raw extract is concentrated and derivatized with diazomethane to produce the corresponding methyl ester derivatives.  (Suitable substitute derivatives may be produced by other available techniques.)  If required, the extracts are cleaned up by Florisil column chromatography.  The derivatives are analyzed by gas chromatography with flame ionization detection.

To understand the extent of human exposure to B[a]P and other PAHs, a reliable sampling and analytical method has been established which involves a combination quartz fibre filter/absorbent cartridge with subsequent extraction and analysis by gas chromatography (GC) with mass spectrometry (MS) detection (GC/MS).  The analytical methods are a modification of EPA Test Method 625, Methods for Organic Chemical Analysis of Municipal and Industrial Wastewater, and Methods 8270, Test Methods for Evaluation of Solid Waste.  PAH1 utilizes PUF as an adsorbant; PAH2 utilizes XAD-2 as an adsorbant.  Note that isotopic surrogates may be added and are reported as % recovery.

The analytical methods are a modification of EPA Test Method 625, Methods for Organic Chemical Analysis of Municipal and Industrial Wastewater, and Methods 8270, Test Methods for Evaluation of Solid Waste.  PAH1 utilizes PUF as an adsorbant; PAH2 utilizes XAD-2 as an adsorbant.  Note that isotopic surrogates may be added and are reported as % recovery.

Performance Based Method. Samples are dried at 60 C and sieved using a .149 mm (100 mesh) sieve.  Solid samples are digested with the combination of nitric and hydrochloric acids with a 1: 1 ratio of acids.  For environmental purposes, strong acid leaches are used routinely since they have the advantage of speed, low cost, and superio reproducibility.  All metals trapped within the refractory matrix are unlikely to have environmental consequences.  Instrumental analysis of extracts produced using this digestion method can be performed by a variety of techniques.

PBDE-1614-HRMS-BU (USEPA 1614) Samples are liquid/liquid extracted with dichloromethane. Calculation of Total PCB.  Total PCB is the sum of the concentrations of PCB aroclors 1016, 1221, 1232, 1242, 1248, 1254, 1260, 1262, and 1268.  Results below detection limit (DL) are treated as zero.  The Total PCB detection limit is equal to the highest of the aroclor detection limits used in the sum.

The NO2 passive sample system uses a specially designed rain shelter to allow the passive sampler to be installed face downwards and to allow the air movement to cross the surface of the diffusion barrier. After exposure, the sampler media is extracted in the laboratory with de-ionized (DI) water. The extract is analyzed by Ion Chromatography. The sampling rate of the passive sampler is calculated using an equation which takes into account the dependence on associated meteorological factors.

Method Name: Separation of resin and fatty acids (RFAs) in water by GC/MS
Method Description: Scientific Principle The separation of resin and fatty acids (RFAs) in water samples is performed using gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS) in the Selected Ion Monitoring (SIM) mode. The separation is based on compound size; boiling point and polarity. Analyte concentration is calculated using the internal standard method. RFA compounds are extracted from water samples using a liquid-liquid solvent extraction with DCM. Extraction occurs after the sample is brought to a pH of ~ 2 and placed in a rotary tumbler (at approx. 40 rpm) for 1 hour. The resulting extract is transferred to a vial; dried with acidified baked sodium sulfate; methylated with diazomethane and concentrated to 1mL under nitrogen prior to analysis. The resulting extracts are vialed and fortified with labeled internal standard compounds prior to analysis by gas chromatography with a (50%-Phenyl)-methylpolysiloxane (DB-17) column and a mass spectrometer detector in SIM Mode.

Method Description: Scientific Principle The separation of resin and fatty acids (RFAs) in water samples is performed using gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS) in the Selected Ion Monitoring (SIM) mode. The separation is based on compound size; boiling point and polarity. Analyte concentration is calculated using the internal standard method. RFA compounds are extracted from water samples using a liquid-liquid solvent extraction with DCM. Extraction occurs after the sample is brought to a pH of ~ 2 and placed in a rotary tumbler (at approx. 40 rpm) for 1 hour. The resulting extract is transferred to a vial; dried with acidified baked sodium sulfate; methylated with diazomethane and concentrated to 1mL under nitrogen prior to analysis. The resulting extracts are vialed and fortified with labeled internal standard compounds prior to analysis by gas chromatography with a (50%-Phenyl)-methylpolysiloxane (DB-17) column and a mass spectrometer detector in SIM Mode.

EC Test Method Biological Test Method: Procedure for pH Stabilization During the Testing of Acute Lethality of Wastewater Effluent to Rainbow Trout; EPS 1/RM/50 - March 2008. A revised version of this method has been developed specifically for pulp and paper effluents; EPS 1/RM/59; March 2018. This method is specific for the pH controller technique described in EPS 1/RM/50 as an add on to the acute fish toxicity test; EPS 1/RM/13.  Method Summary Rainbow Trout are exposed in single or multiple concentration(s) of the sample and mortality is recorded over a period of 96 hours at 15?1?C. The pass/fail single concentration test uses undiluted material at 100% concentration and determines the percent mortality after 96 hours. The LC50 and LC20 tests use multiple concentrations of material diluted in laboratory water and determines the concentration of that is lethal to 50% and 20% of the test fish respectively. Parallel testing with and without pH stabilization is recommended to demonstrate the presence of ammonia toxicity.  Upward pH drift in the effluent test solution causes an increase in the concentration of un-ionized ammonia which is the most acutely toxic form present. The loss of CO2 is caused by the standard test procedure of aerating the effluent sample with lab air. The pH stabilization is intended to replace the CO2 lost during aeration in order to maintain the pH throughout the test at the same level found in the original sample. The pH stabilization is accomplished by using either the CO2 injection or the pH controller techniques. The procedure is only applicable when used explicitly with conjunction to the reference method EPS 1/RM/13 ?Biological Test Method: Reference Method for Determining Acute Lethality of Effluents to Rainbow Trout?. The pH stabilization applies to both single and multiple concentration tests.  Applications For use only with wastewater effluents. The LC50 test is required for permitted discharges.

Saturation Percentage (SP) is the total volume of water present in a saturated paste (in mL) divided by the dry weight of the sample (in grams), expressed as a percentage, as described in "Soil Sampling and Methods of Analysis" by M. Carter.

Salinity in Water  PURPOSE/PRINCIPLE OF METHOD: There are two definitions of the term salinity, absolute salinity and practical salinity.  Absolute salinity is defined as the ratio of the mass of dissolved material in seawater to the mass of the seawater. This salinity cannot be measured directly and thus the practical salinity value has been adopted as the standard for reporting salinity values. Practical salinity is defined as the ratio of the electrical conductivity of a sample to that of a standard potassium chloride (KCl) solution at the same temperature and pressure. The salinity dependence of the conductivity ratio as a function of temperature of a given sample to a standard S=35 seawater sample is used to determine the salinity. In water, ions such as calcium, magnesium, sodium bicarbonate, nitrate, phosphate, iron, and sulphate all contribute to the salinity. Conductivity accounts for all ions in solution and provides no specific information regarding the type and concentration of any particular ion. Instead, a reading proportional to the combined effect of all ions is reported. SCOPE: Salinity is an important unitless property of industrial and natural waters. Because of its high sensitivity and ease of measurement, the conductivity method is most commonly used to determine salinity. DETECTION LIMITS: RDL =0.01 REFERENCE: Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, 22nd Edition, American Public Health Association, Washington, DC, 2011, Method 2520 B Salinity, Electrical Conductivity Method.

Sample extraction methods vary due to properties unique to the sample type. Water samples are typically liquid / liquid DCM extraction, however the analyst may decide that another solvent such as Hexane is more appropriate. For sediment and biota samples, extraction methods include Microwave Assisted Process and wrist or platform shaker. Again solvent choice is at the discretion of teh analyst and may include DCM, Methanol, Acetone, Hexane, or others. For samples such as raw products, no extraction may be necessary and simple dilution in an appropriate solvent may be all that is required. The extract is analyzed using High Resolution Gas Chromatography / Low Resolution Mass Spectrometry (HRGC/LRMS). MS data is acquired in Full Scan Mode (Scan) and normally no quantitation is performed.

Titanium in Tissue by CRC ICPMS (WET)              Methodology: This method is conducted following British Columbia Lab Manual method "Metals in Animal Tissue and Vegetation (Biota) - Prescriptive". Tissue samples are homogenized and sub-sampled prior to hotblock digestion with nitric and hydrochloric acids, in combination with addition of hydrogen peroxide.  Instrumental analysis is by collision cell inductively coupled plasma - mass spectrometry (modified from EPA Method 6020A).  Method Limitation: This method employs a strong acid/peroxide digestion, and is intended to provide a conservative estimate of bio-available metals.  Near complete recoveries are achieved for most toxicologically important metals, but elements associated with recalcitrant minerals may be only partially recovered.

Method Name: Total Metals in Water by ICPMS (Ultra)
Method Description: Total Metals in Water by ICPMS (Ultra), EPA SW-846 3005A/6020A, MET-TOT-ULTRA-MS-VA This analysis is carried out using procedures adapted from "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" published by the American Public Health Association, and with procedures adapted from "Test Methods for Evaluating Solid Waste" SW-846 published by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The procedures may involve preliminary sample treatment by acid digestion, using either hotblock or microwave oven, or filtration (EPA Method 3005A).  Instrumental analysis is by inductively coupled plasma - mass spectrometry (EPA Method 6020A).

Method Name: CNS Analysis in Soil: Vario El Cube
Method Description: Elemental Analysis of Soil Samples by Elementar Vario Cube EL.  DOCUMENT # CAL SOP-00263. Reference Method: Application Note, Elementar Form No. AN-A-030609-E-01, CNS analysis in soil with the vario EL Cube SECTION 1: Introduction  The Vario El Cube is an elemental analyzer that uses a thermal conductivity detector to determine Carbon, Hydrogen, Nitrogen, and Sulfur in a soil sample. The thermal conductivity detector contains two chambers, one measuring cell for the analysis gas and a reference cell for the carrier gas. Both gases will flow through the cell during analysis. The gases will mix and cause a difference in electrical charge which is measured by a microcontroller. The microcontroller will convert and integrate the electrical signal into a digitized one. The signal is displayed as a measuring peak dependent on the time. The elemental content of the sample will be calculated from the integrals of the individual measuring peaks and the calibration factors of the elements.   SECTION 2: Scope  This procedure is applicable to the determination of Carbon, Organic Carbon, Hydrogen, Nitrogen and Sulphur in solids.  SECTION 3: Reporting Detection Limits  Total Nitrogen: 0.20% Total Carbon: 0.02% Total Organic Carbon: 0.02%  Total Sulfur: 0.03%  SECTION 4: Interferences  4.1 All samples are to be dried and ground as per AB SOP-00035: Grinding of Soil Samples to ensure all moisture is removed. During analysis the sample gas passes through reagent tubes containing anhydrone (magnesium perchlorate) to remove any water vapor produced during combustion.  4.2 Some samples may react strongly when the HCL is added which could cause a loss of sample. If this occurs a dilution must be done and the acid must be added drop by drop. SECTION 5: Sample Hold Time and Preservation  No specific holding time is stated in the reference method. It is Maxxam?s policy to discard samples 60 days after analysis. No preservation required, store dry samples at ambient Temperature.

Volatile Fatty Acids by GC/FID; Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater; 21st Edition, Method 5560 D; pages 5-59 to 5-61.  5560 D. Gas Chromatographic Method Principle: This gas chromatographic procedure may be usedto determine the individual concentrations of the following fattyacids: acetic; propionic; butyric; isobutyric; valeric; andisovaleric acids in digester sludge samples. Caproic and heptanoicacids also may be determined; but with less certaintybecause of their reduced solubility in water. Volatile fatty acidsare generally soluble in digester sludge and exist in either theprotonated or unprotonated form; depending on the pH of thesludge sample. Acetic and propionic acids usually are in higherconcentrations than the other fatty acids in digester sludge. Allacids must be converted to the protonated (volatile) form beforeinjection into the gas chromatograph (GC) so vaporization mayoccur. The fatty acids must also be separated from the solidsmaterial in the sample before introduction into the GC to minimizedegradation of the GC column. Digester sludge samples areprepared by acidification; centrifugation; and filtration. The sampleis analyzed by direct injection into a gas chromatographequipped with a flame ionization detector after both centrifugationand filtration.b. Interference: The blank amount may be high relative tosample analyte. High blanks may be caused by a buildup ofcontaminants in the injector and guard column or by samplecarry-over. The analyst must be aware of the blank levels andcorrect unacceptably high blank levels that are above the reportinglimits.c. Minimum detectable concentration: The method detectionlevel has been determined by the USEPA method1 in reagentwater to be about 3 mg/L for acetic acid and about 1 mg/L for allother target compounds.
