Acetic and propionic acids usually are in higherconcentrations than the other fatty acids in digester sludge. Allacids must be converted to the protonated (volatile) form beforeinjection into the gas chromatograph (GC) so vaporization mayoccur. The fatty acids must also be separated from the solidsmaterial in the sample before introduction into the GC to minimizedegradation of the GC column. Digester sludge samples areprepared by acidification; centrifugation; and filtration. The sampleis analyzed by direct injection into a gas chromatographequipped with a flame ionization detector after both centrifugationand filtration.b. Interference: The blank amount may be high relative tosample analyte. High blanks may be caused by a buildup ofcontaminants in the injector and guard column or by samplecarry-over. The analyst must be aware of the blank levels andcorrect unacceptably high blank levels that are above the reportinglimits.c. Minimum detectable concentration: The method detectionlevel has been determined by the USEPA method1 in reagentwater to be about 3 mg/L for acetic acid and about 1 mg/L for allother target compounds.

ALS Minerals OA-VOL11.  Net Acid Generation (NAG) provides a quantitative estimation of the acid that can be generated by mine waste. Hydrogen peroxide is used to rapidly oxidize sulfides. NAG is reported in kg H2SO4/tonne at pH 4.5 and 7.0.
Observed Property ID: Net Acid Generation (as H2SO4 pH 4.5) (mass conc.)

A Single Wavelength Colour of a sample is determined by measuring the absorbance of the filtered sample at 465 nm after filtering and adjustment of pH to 7.6.  One unit of SWC colour may be defined as the colour produced by 1 mg Pt/L in the form of choloroplatinate ion.  Measurements at 466 nm are considered equivalent.

Filter Paper; Dry 600C

The biochemical oxygen demand is determined by measuring the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) that is consumed in the sample under aerobic conditions during the incubation period (five days at 20 C) after seeding material has been added.  A polarographic membrane electrode that has been calibrated in saturated air is used to acquire all dissolved oxygen measurements.  Nitrification inhibitor added.  A modified Winkler procedure may be substituted for the DO probe procedure. Performance Base Method published circa Dec. 2000.

Multiple-tube fermentation technique is the examination of replicate tubes and dilutions reported in terms of Most Probable Number (MPN) of organisms present. This number, based on certain probability formulas, is an estimate of the mean density of bacteria in the sample. MPN method is not influenced by turbidity.

A well-mixed sample is filtered through a standard 0.1 um glass fibre filter.  A measured portion of the filtrate is evaporated in a preweighed evaporating vessel and dried to constant weight at 180 C.  The increase in dish weight represents the total dissolved solids.  (The filtrate from residue, non-filterable may be used.)

The filtered sample is passed through a column containing granulated copper-cadmium which reduces Nitrate to Nitrite.  Quantitative reduction is ensured by maintaining a stable H-ion concentration through addition of ammonium chloride (NH4Cl).  The Nitrite that is originally present in the sample plus the reduced Nitrate then react with sulfanilamide under acidic conditions to form a diazo compound.  This compound then complexes with N-1-naphthylethylenediamine dihydrochloride to form a reddish purple azo dye, the absorbance of which is measured at 550 nm.  Nitrate (NO3) concentration can be calculated using the Nitrate & Nitrite result and subtracting the Nitrite result (NO23 - NO2 = NO3).  Manual analysis.

The sample is acidified and sparged with an inert gas.  Hydrogen sulfide, thus liberated, is trapped in a zinc acetate solution.  Excess iodine is added and back-titrated with standard sodium thiosulfate solution. Iodine consumed is equivalent to the trapped sulfide.

a) For Ca, the sample pH is adjusted to pH 12-13 so that the magnesium is precipitated as the hydroxide. Next, the sample is titrated with EDTA in the presence of an indicator. When sufficient EDTA has been added so as to complex all the calcium ions the indicator changes color. Results reported as mg/L as Ca. b) For hardness, a sample buffered to pH 10.0+/-0.1 is titrated with EDTA in the presence of an indicator. When sufficient EDTA has been added in order to complex all the calcium and magnesium ions the indicator changes color. Results reported as mg/L as CaCO3.

a) For Ca, the sample pH is adjusted to pH 12-13 so that the magnesium is precipitated as the hydroxide. Next, the sample is titrated with EDTA in the presence of an indicator. When sufficient EDTA has been added so as to complex all the calcium ions the indicator changes color. Results reported as mg/L as Ca. b) For hardness, a sample buffered to pH 10.0+/-0.1 is titrated with EDTA in the presence of an indicator. When sufficient EDTA has been added in order to complex all the calcium and magnesium ions the indicator changes color. Results reported as mg/L as CaCO3.

The pH of the sample is determined and a measured amount of standard acid is added, as needed, to lower the pH to 4 or less.  Hydrogen peroxide is added, the solution boiled for several minutes, cooled and titrated to pH 8.3 with standard base.  The method measures the mineral acidity of the sample plus acidity from oxidation and hydrolysis of polyvalent cations, including salts of iron and aluminum.  Because the color change of phenolphthalein indicator is close to pH 8.3, this value generally is accepted as a standard end point for titration of total acidity, including CO2 and most weak acids.
A known volume of a well-mixed sample is transferred into an ignited and weighed porcelain dish, evaporated, dried and weighed.  The difference in weights represents Total Residue.
Calc; TRes-NFRes

A clear (Total) or filtered (Dissolved) water sample is injected into a stream of carbonate-bicarbonate eluent and passed through a series of ion exchanger.  The anions of interested are separated on the basis of their relative affinities for a low capacity , strongly basic anion exchanger (guard and separate columns).  The separated anions are directed through the anion self-regenerating suppressor (ASRS).  Hydronium ions in the suppressor will neutralize the eluent to its weakly ionized form and convert the separated anions in their conductive acid form.  The separated anions are measured by conductivity.  They are identified on the basis of retention time as compared to standards.  Quantitation is by measurement of peak area of peak height against a calibration curve generated from known standards.

A clear (Total) or filtered (Dissolved) water sample is injected into a stream of carbonate-bicarbonate eluent and passed through a series of ion exchanger.  The anions of interested are separated on the basis of their relative affinities for a low capacity , strongly basic anion exchanger (guard and separate columns).  The separated anions are directed through the anion self-regenerating suppressor (ASRS).  Hydronium ions in the suppressor will neutralize the eluent to its weakly ionized form and convert the separated anions in their conductive acid form.  The separated anions are measured by conductivity.  They are identified on the basis of retention time as compared to standards.  Quantitation is by measurement of peak area of peak height against a calibration curve generated from known standards.

Sulfate is precipitated as barium sulfate (BaSO4) in HCl medium by the addition of barium chloride.  After the digestion period, the precipitate is filtered, washed with hot water until chloride free, ignited and weighed as BaSO4.

Sulfate is precipitated as barium sulfate (BaSO4) in HCl medium by the addition of barium chloride.  After the digestion period, the precipitate is filtered, washed with hot water until chloride free, ignited and weighed as BaSO4.

The pH of the sample is determined and a measured amount of standard acid is added, as needed, to lower the pH to 4 or less.  Hydrogen peroxide is added, the solution boiled for several minutes, cooled and titrated to pH 8.3 with standard base.  The method measures the mineral acidity of the sample plus acidity from oxidation and hydrolysis of polyvalent cations, including salts of iron and aluminum.  pH 8.3 end point determined by manual potentiometric titration.

Inorganic arsenic is reduced to arsine, AsH3, by zinc in an acid medium. The arsine then passes from the generator flask through a lead acetate scrubber and into an absorber tube containing silver diethyldithiocarbamate dissolved in pyridine. In the absorber, the arsine reacts with the silver salt to form a soluble red colored complex which is measured colorimetrically at 535nm or 540 nm.

In the absorber, the arsine reacts with the silver salt to form a soluble red colored complex which is measured colorimetrically at 535nm or 540 nm.

The biochemical oxygen demand is determined by measuring the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) that is consumed in the sample under aerobic conditions during the incubation period (five days at 20 C).  A polarographic membrane electrode that has been calibrated in saturated air is used to acquire all dissolved oxygen measurements.  Nitrification inhibitor added.  No seed is added.  A modified Winkler procedure may be substituted for the DO probe procedure. Performance Base Method published circa Dec. 2000.

The unfiltered preserved sample is distilled under acidic conditions to remove most interferences.  The addition of 4-aminoantipyrine in the presence of potassium ferricyanide forms a red coloured antipyrine dye which remains in an aqueous solution and the absorbance is measured at 505 nm.  This method determines phenol, ortho- and meta- substituted phenols as phenol.

The filtered sample is reacted with a mixture of ammonium molybdate and potassium antimonyl tartrate in acid solution.  Ascorbic acid is then added to produce a blue coloured product with an absorbance maximum at 880 nm.  The absorbance of the solution is measured and the phosphorus concentration is determined by comparison with standards treated in the same manner.  Automated procedure.

The filtered sample is acidified, potassium persulfate is added and the mixture is digested at elevated temperature and pressure in a steam autoclave.  After digestion, the sample is reacted with a mixture of ammonium molybdate and potassium antimonyl tartrate in acid solution.  Ascorbic acid is then added to produce a blue coloured product with an absorbance maximum at 880 nm.  The absorbance of the solution is measured and the phosphorus concentration is determined by comparison with standards treated in the same manner.
Auto Flame Emission
Auto Flame Emission

Not all forms of silica in solution will react to give the silicomolybdate complex.  Silicic acid readily polymerizes at the pH of seawater (pH=8.0), and only straight chain polymers of relatively short length will react with molybdate at any appreciable speed.  Therefore, the term "Reactive Silica" is best used.  This automated procedure for the determination of reactive silica is based on the reduction by ascorbic acid of silicomolybdate in acidic solution to heteropoly blue.  The colour is measured at 660 nm in a 1.5 cm cell.  Oxalic acid is introduced to the sample stream before the addition of ascorbic acid to eliminate interference from phosphates.  The sample should be collected in a clean linear polyethylene bottle.  The samples are not preserved.  The samples should be free from turbidity.  Allow the samples to settle before decanting an aliquot, or filter the samples through 0.45 m filter paper.  Samples are stored at 4C prior to analysis.  The samples should be analysed within 28 days.  Note: Do not use glass containers.

This code is a catch-all for a large variety of ICP methods including water and also solids digested into solutions as an intermediate result.  Different procedures will have greatly different detection limits.  (a) For air particulates, preliminary results are reported in mg/L and loading results as mg/dm2/d. (b) For Hi Vol samples preliminiary results are same as reported in mg/L and loading results as ug/m3.  (c) Note that for Rain samples there is no filtration nor digestion steps.

Different procedures will have greatly different detection limits.  (a) For air particulates, preliminary results are reported in mg/L and loading results as mg/dm2/d. (b) For Hi Vol samples preliminiary results are same as reported in mg/L and loading results as ug/m3.  (c) Note that for Rain samples there is no filtration nor digestion steps.

Analysis is comprised of 2 phases, the determination of Total Carbon (TC) or Dissolved Carbon (DC) and the determination of Total Inorganic Carbon (TIC) or Dissolved Inorganic Carbon (DIC).  Total Organic Carbon (TOC) content, or Dissolved Organic Carbon (DOC) is then calculated by difference.  A series of External Standard solutions, Potassium Biphthalate for TC (DC) and Sodium Carbonate/Sodium Bicarbonate for TIC (DIC) is used for instrument calibration.  During TC (DC) analysis, a small portion of the sample (or standard) solution is introduced into a combustion tube, containing a Platinum catalyst at an elevated temperature with an Oxygen gas carrier, via an automated autosampler/injector.  The sample's TC (DC) component is combusted/oxidized to form CO2.  The CO2 flows through an IC reaction vessel, is cooled and dried by an electronic dehumidifier and passes through a halogen scrubber into a Non-dispersive Infrared Detector (NDIR).  The NDIR produces an analog signal over a constant time base that a data processor converts into a peak, the area of which is proportional to the TC concentration of the sample.  The TC (DC) concentration of a sample is determined electronically from a calibration curve expressing the relationship between the peak area of a standard and its concentration.  Similarly, for the TIC (DIC) phase of the analysis, another small portion of sample (or standard) solution is introduced directly into the IC reaction vessel, containing a Phosphoric Acid solution through which carrier gas is bubbled.  However, here only the IC component of the sample reacts to form CO2.  The TOC (DOC) concentration is automatically determined by the data processor from the difference between TC (DC) and TIC (DOC) concentrations.

Method Name: UV Oxid'n: Cd red'n: diazn: colorimetric
Method Description: Organic nitrogenous compounds, including ammonia, are oxidized by ultraviolet irradiation to a mixture of nitrate and nitrite.  This mixture then is all converted to nitrite in the cadmium reduction column.  These nitrites react with sulphanilamide under acidic conditions to form a diazo compound.  This compound compexes with N-1-naphthylethylenediamine dihydrochloride to form a reddish-purple azo dye, the absorbance of which is measured at 550 nm.

The unfiltered sample is acidified, potassium persulfate is added and the mixture is digested at elevated temperature and pressure in a steam autoclave.  After digestion, the sample is reacted with a mixture of ammonium molybdate and potassium antimonyl tartrate in acid solution.  Ascorbic acid is then added to produce a blue coloured product with an absorbance maximum at 880 nm.  The absorbance of the solution is measured and the phosphorus concentration is determined by comparison with standards treated in the same manner.  Automated procedure.  This unfiltered method is sometimes used for a clear turbid-free solution where filtering is not considered necessary.

The sample is dried, ground to pass 100 mesh, and digested with a nitric-hydrochloric acid mixture to solubilize the solid matter and to remove the organic material by oxidation and volatilization.  The completed digests are submitted to metals instrumentation personnel for metals analysis by Inductively Coupled Atomic Emission Spectrophotometry (ICP-AES), or hydride analysis by atomic absorption.

The procedure consists of first air drying a subsample of sediment at room temperature.  The dried sample is then digested with concetrated hydrochloric acid to remove inorganic carbon.  The acid treated sample is dried at 60C. Iron tin fines are added to the sample prior to combustion in a Leco Induction Furnace.  Carbon is determined volumetrically.  Results are reported on a dry-weight basis.
Lipid material is extracted from the tissue with a suitable solvent, the solvent is removed by heating and the residue is determined gravimetrically.
The sample is homogenized, and moisture is removed by heating at 105 C, and the residue is determined gravimetrically.  (Oven drying at 103 - 105 C is taken as equivalent.)

Liquid Scintillation

Sample is ground and dried then subjected to hydrogen peroxide or sulphuric acid digestion in a block digestor which converts the Kjeldahl nitrogen containing compounds to ammonium sulphate and carbon dioxide. The digest is then taken up by an auto analyzer, neutralized and reacted with sodium salicylate and a chlorine source. Using sodium nitroprusside catalyst, a coloured indophenols complex is formed and absorbance at 660nm is measured.

Soil or sediment samples are homogenized and sub-samples taken.  Without a drying step, samples are digested with Aqua Regia either over a hot plate or in a microwave.  Solubidized mercury is then analyzed by CVAAS.  A separate sub-sample is analyzed for moisture and the mercury result corrected to dry value.

Iso-octaneExt: GC/ECD

C-13 labelled PCDD and PCDF congeners are added to a 1L sample of pulp effluent, which is separated into solid and liquid phases by filtration through a glass fibre filter. The solid phase is aire-dried overnight before undergoing a Soxhlet extraction with toluene. The liquid phase is extracted with dichloromethane in a separatory funnel. The two extracts are combined, concentrated, and then passed through a series of columns which remove the bulk of the organic matrix co-extracted with PCDD/PCDF. One resulting fraction is concentrated to a known small volume for analysis by HRGC/HRMS/DS.

The sample is placed in a separatory funnel, the pH of the sample is adjusted to alkaline and then acidic conditions, and extracted each time with dichloromethane to selectively remove compounds.  The final extracts (basic and acidic) can be combined or run separately.  The extract is cleaned by silica gel column chromatography, then analyzed by GC/MS.

An aqueous sample is treated, as required, with Sodium Sulphite to remove any residual Chlorine and acidified with Nitric Acid.  An aliquot of the sample, the actual dilution dependent on the estimated AOX concentration, is passed at a precisely controlled flow rate through an assembly of two granular activated carbon (GAC) columns connected in series.  The GAC in the column assembly is then "washed" with a nitrate solution to desorb any inorganic halides.  The GAC from each column is separately pyrolysed at high temperature in a controlled atmosphere and the resulting "HX" gases are purged through a dehydrating tube into a Chlorine Detection Cell, automatically kept at a preset potential, where the sample is trapped in an Acetic Acid electrolyte and microcoulometrically titrated with silver ions.  Monitoring, integration and conversion of the cell EMF to concentration units is accomplished electronically.

Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs) In Water by Gas Chromatography-Electron Capture Detector (GC/ECD).  A water sample, usually 1000 mL, is extracted using dichloromethane. Sulphuric acid clean-up step is performed in every sample. Dirty samples with dark colored extracts are put through a clean-up step using 2% Deactivated Florisil. If sulphur is present in the water samples, especially for the river or stream water samples, a copper metal clean-up step may be used. A final analysis is performed using a GC equipped with an ECD. SCOPE: This procedure describes the determination of PCBs in water. If Organochlorine Pesticides (OC's) and PCB's are to be analyzed on the same water sample, a separate test method (Method for the Determination of Pesticides in Water by GC/MS and LC/MS or HPLC Fluorescence Detection DCN 62-C-043) is used.  DETECTION LIMITS: Target Compound Reported Detection Limit (mg/L) Arochlor 1221 0.1 Arochlor 1242 0.1 Arochlor 1248 0.1 Arochlor 1254 0.1 Arochlor 1260 0.1 INTERFERENCES: Interferences (e.g. co-eluting peaks on the chromatogram) may be due to sulfur,phthalate esters, or from chlorinated compounds. Suspect samples must be reanalyzed using appropriate cleanup steps. SAMPLE HANDLING & PRESERVATION: Sample Containers: For sample collection, use 1 litre amber glass bottles that have been pre-rinsed with acetone and hexane then dried. Bottle lids must be teflon-lined, or alternatively lined with solvent-rinsed aluminium foil. Shipment and Storage: Samples must be refrigerated (at 2-8C) and stored in the dark. Holding Time: Samples must be extracted within 7 days of sampling; REFERENCE: U.S. EPA Method 8080: Organochlorine Pesticides and PCB's Analysis. SW-846 3rd Ed.,September, 1986.

For alkalinity, the samples are (if pH >8.3) first titrated to a pH of 8.3, which corresponds to the equivalence point for the conversion of carbonate to bicarbonate ion (phenolphthalein alkalinity).  The titration is continued to a pH of 4.5, which corresponds approx. to the equivalence point for the conversion of bicarbonate ion to carbonic acid (entire titration indicates total alkalinity).  An extrapolation technique based on the near proportionality of concentration of H ions to excess of titrant beyond the equivalence pt.  The amount of standard acid required to reduce pH exactly 0.30pH (ie. pH4.2) unit is measured carefully.  Because this change in pH corresponds to an exact coupling of the H ion concentration, a simple extrapolation can be made to the equivalence point.  The actual pH of the stoichiometric end point in alkalinity determinations is the pH at which the inflection in the titration curve occurs and is directly related to the amount of carbonate alkalinity originally present in the sample.  A curve can be constructed by plotting pH vs mL of acid to find this point directly.  *** For acidity, the samples are titrated to a pH of 8.3, which corresponds to stoichiometric neutralization of carbonic acid to bicarbonate.  Because the colour change of phenolphthalein indicator is close to pH 8.3, this value generally is accepted as a standard end point for titration of total acidity, including CO2 and most weak acids an equivalence point for the conversion of carbonate to bicarbonate ion (phenolphthalein alkalinity).  The actual pH of the stoichiometric end point in acidity determinations is the pH at which the inflection in the titration curve occurs and is directly related to the amount of titratable acids originally present in the sample.  A curve can be constructed by plotting pH vs. mL of NaOH to find this point directly. (To obtain the actual substances contributing to acidity/alkalinity, a pH vs mL of acid/NaOH curve should be constructed.)

A curve can be constructed by plotting pH vs mL of acid to find this point directly.  *** For acidity, the samples are titrated to a pH of 8.3, which corresponds to stoichiometric neutralization of carbonic acid to bicarbonate.  Because the colour change of phenolphthalein indicator is close to pH 8.3, this value generally is accepted as a standard end point for titration of total acidity, including CO2 and most weak acids an equivalence point for the conversion of carbonate to bicarbonate ion (phenolphthalein alkalinity).  The actual pH of the stoichiometric end point in acidity determinations is the pH at which the inflection in the titration curve occurs and is directly related to the amount of titratable acids originally present in the sample.  A curve can be constructed by plotting pH vs. mL of NaOH to find this point directly. (To obtain the actual substances contributing to acidity/alkalinity, a pH vs mL of acid/NaOH curve should be constructed.)

For alkalinity, the samples are (if pH >8.3) first titrated to a pH of 8.3, which corresponds to the equivalence point for the conversion of carbonate to bicarbonate ion (phenolphthalein alkalinity).  The titration is continued to a pH of 4.5, which corresponds approx. to the equivalence point for the conversion of bicarbonate ion to carbonic acid (entire titration indicates total alkalinity).  An extrapolation technique based on the near proportionality of concentration of H ions to excess of titrant beyond the equivalence pt.  The amount of standard acid required to reduce pH exactly 0.30pH (ie. pH4.2) unit is measured carefully.  Because this change in pH corresponds to an exact coupling of the H ion concentration, a simple extrapolation can be made to the equivalence point.  The actual pH of the stoichiometric end point in alkalinity determinations is the pH at which the inflection in the titration curve occurs and is directly related to the amount of carbonate alkalinity originally present in the sample.  A curve can be constructed by plotting pH vs mL of acid to find this point directly.  *** For acidity, the samples are titrated to a pH of 8.3, which corresponds to stoichiometric neutralization of carbonic acid to bicarbonate.  Because the colour change of phenolphthalein indicator is close to pH 8.3, this value generally is accepted as a standard end point for titration of total acidity, including CO2 and most weak acids an equivalence point for the conversion of carbonate to bicarbonate ion (phenolphthalein alkalinity).  The actual pH of the stoichiometric end point in acidity determinations is the pH at which the inflection in the titration curve occurs and is directly related to the amount of titratable acids originally present in the sample.  A curve can be constructed by plotting pH vs. mL of NaOH to find this point directly. (To obtain the actual substances contributing to acidity/alkalinity, a pH vs mL of acid/NaOH curve should be constructed.)

An appropriate sample aliquot is passed through two granular activated carbon (GAC) columns in series where the organo-halides are adsorbed.  The columns are then rinsed with 0.8M potassium nitrate solution to remove inorganic halides.  The columns are combusted individually and the generated halo-acids are collected and measured in a microcoulometric cell.

A measured volume of sample is filtered through a 0.45 um membrane filter or a pre-rinsed dried and pre-weighed glass fibre filter.  The filter is rinsed, removed from the filtration apparatus and dried at 105 C for 24 hours than cooled in a desiccator and reweighed.  Results may be reported in units of mg (per whole sample) but final results should be reported either in mg/L or mg/m2, whichever is appropriate.
Organic carbon is converted to carbon dioxide (CO2) by catalytic combustion or wet chemistry oxidation.  The CO2 is then converted to methane (CH4) and measured by flame ionization detector.

Organic and oxidizable inorganic substances are oxidized by potassium dichromate in H2SO4 solution at reflux temperature for 2 hours.  Excess dichromate is titrated with standard ferrous ammonium sulfate (0.1M) using orthophenanthroline ferrous complex (ferroin) as indicator.  Open Reflux.

Organic and oxidizable inorganic substances are oxidized by potassium dichromate in H2SO4 solution at reflux temperature for 2 hours.  Excess dichromate is titrated with standard ferrous ammonium sulfate (0.1M) using orthophenanthroline ferrous complex (ferroin) as indicator.  Open Reflux.

Thiocyanate ion (SCN) is liberated from mercuric thiocyanate through sequestration of mercury by chloride ion to form un-ionized mercuric chloride.  Ferric nitrate reagent provides ferric ion which, with SCN, forms highly coloured ferric thiocyanate in a concentration proportional to the original chloride concentration.  The instrument range of 0.5 to 50 mg/L may be extended with sample dilution.  Where particulate matter is present, the sample must be filtered or centrifuged prior to the determination.

Known amount of reducing agent (usually phenylarsine oxide) is added, and the excess reducing agent after reaction with chlorine residual is determined by iodometric titration, amperiometric endpoint.
The sample is centrifuged or filtered to remove turbidity and colour is determined by visual comparison of the sample with known concentrations of coloured solutions.

This analysis is carried out using procedures adapted from APHA Method 2540 "Solids". Solids are determined gravimetrically. Fixed Solids is determined by ashing (at 550C) the residue of a sample evaporated to dryness.

An aliquot of the alkaline distillate from the analyst's choice of digestion procedure is buffered to pH<8 and reacted with chloramine-T.  Isonicotinic acid - barbituric acid solution is added and the absorption of the solution is measured at 578 nm.  Soils and sediments can be analyzed by suspension in the digestion solution.

The sample is subjected to a strong acid [hydrochloric acid - hydroxylamine hydrochloride] reflux digestion/distillation.  HCN is liberated and trapped in a weak NaOH solution.  An aliquot of this solution is then analyzed by a colorimetric technique, ref. Isonicotinic - Barbituric Acid method.

The sample is heated in the presence of sulfuric acid, potassium sulfate and mercuric sulfate for 2.5 hours.  The digest is cooled, diluted to 25 mL and placed on the autoanalyzer for NH3 determination.

Alkaline phenol and hypochlorite react with ammonia to form indophenol blue that is proportional to ammonia concentration.  Sodium nitroprusside intensifies the blue colour thus formed.  Analyses are performed with an autoanalyzer with spectrometer and 630-660 nm filters and 15 mm or 50 mm tubular flow cell.  A manual version of this method may also be employed.  Note that calcium and magnesium ions may be present in concentrations sufficient to cause precipitation problems during analysis.  Also, sample turbidity and colour may interfere with this method.

Nitrites react with sulphanilamide under acidic conditions to form a diazo compound.  This compound compexes with N-1-naphthylethylene diamine dihydrochloride to form a reddish-purple azo dye, the absorbance of which is measured at 540 nm.

The filtered sample is passed through a column containing granulated copper-cadmium which reduces Nitrate to Nitrite.  Quantitative reduction is ensured by maintaining a stable H-ion concentration through addition of ammonium chloride (NH4Cl).  The Nitrite that is originally present in the sample plus the reduced Nitrate then react with sulfanilamide under acidic conditions to form a diazo compound.  This compound then complexes with N-1-naphthylethylenediamine dihydrochloride to form a reddish purple azo dye, the absorbance of which is measured at 550 nm.  Nitrate (NO3) concentration can be calculated using the Nitrate & Nitrite result and subtracting the Nitrite result (NO23 - NO2 = NO3).  Automated analysis.
The sample is automatically digested with a sulfuric acid solution containing a metal catalyst.  Organic nitrogen is converted to ammonium sulfate.

The conductance (= conductivity) of a sample is measured by use of a self-contained conductivity meter. pH is measured with a combined glass/reference (Ag/AgCl) electrode.  For both conductivity and pH the measurements are made at 25 C, or the results are temperature-corrected to 25 C.  Note that laboratory and field measurements are distinguished by the EMS Analytical Agency codes.  Ex situ and in situ measurements are distinguished by the computer codes.

The conductance (= conductivity) of a sample is measured by use of a self-contained conductivity meter. pH is measured with a combined glass/reference (Ag/AgCl) electrode.  For both conductivity and pH the measurements are made at 25 C, or the results are temperature-corrected to 25 C.  Note that laboratory and field measurements are distinguished by the EMS Analytical Agency codes.  Ex situ and in situ measurements are distinguished by the computer codes.

The conductance (= conductivity) of a sample is measured by use of a self-contained conductivity meter. pH is measured with a combined glass/reference (Ag/AgCl) electrode.  For both conductivity and pH the measurements are made at 25 C, or the results are temperature-corrected to 25 C.  Note that laboratory and field measurements are distinguished by the EMS Analytical Agency codes.  Ex situ and in situ measurements are distinguished by the computer codes.

The conductance (= conductivity) of a sample is measured by use of a self-contained conductivity meter. pH is measured with a combined glass/reference (Ag/AgCl) electrode.  For both conductivity and pH the measurements are made at 25 C, or the results are temperature-corrected to 25 C.  Note that laboratory and field measurements are distinguished by the EMS Analytical Agency codes.  Ex situ and in situ measurements are distinguished by the computer codes.
Observed Property ID: Final pH of solvent in leachability methods (acidity)

Note that laboratory and field measurements are distinguished by the EMS Analytical Agency codes.  Ex situ and in situ measurements are distinguished by the computer codes.

The entire sample is filtered, with rinsing, through a pre-weighed glass fibre filter discs (Whatman 934-AH, or equivalent), and the residue on the filter is dried to constant weight at 103 - 105 C.  The increase in weight of the filter is reported as nonfilterable residue.  The filtrate may be used for residue, filterable.
A well mixed sample is evaporated in a pre-weighed dish and dried to constant weight in the oven at 180 C.  The increase in weight over the empty dish represents the total solids.
Ammonium molybdate at pH 1.2 reacts with silica to form yellow molybdosilicic acid which is reduced by ascorbic acid to produce an intensely blue heteropoly acid.  The absorbance is read at 600 nm.
Ammonium molybdate at pH 1.2 reacts with silica to form yellow molybdosilicic acid.  The absorbance is read at 410 nm.

The sample, made just acid to phenolphthalein and treated with an excess of methylene blue, is extracted three times with chloroform (CHCl3).  The combined chloroform extracts are washed with acidic buffer solution, dried and made to volume for colorimetric measurement at 652nm.  The intensity of the resulting blue color in the organic phase is a measure of MBAS.  Linear alkylbezene sulfonate (LAS) is the most widely used anionic surfactant and is used to standardize the MBAS method.  This method is a measure of anionic surfactants.

Filtered sample; no acid digestion.  Uranyl ion, complexed with pyrophosphate, is excited at 337nm with a pulsed nitrogen laser and the resulting fluorescence at 494, 516 or 540 nm is monitored.  The method of standard additions is used to minimize interferences from matrix effects.

Unfiltered sample; HNO3 digestion.  Uranyl ion, complexed with pyrophosphate, is excited at 337 nm with a pulsed nitrogen laser and the resulting fluorescence at 494, 516 or 540 nm is monitored.  The method of standard additions is used to minimize interferences from matrix effects.
Samples are field-acidified with HCl; HCl digestion; analysis by HVAAS.
The unfiltered field-acidified water sample undergoes a strongly oxidizing digestion.  The sample is then analyzed by CVAAS.
The sample is field filtered (0.45 um) and field acidified (HNO3); strong oxidizing digestion; analysis by CVAA.
Samples are field-filtered (0.45 um) and field-acidified (HCl); analysis by HVAAS.

An aliquot of the water sample is reacted with dinitrofluoro-benzene (DNFB) to form derivatives of glyphosate and AMPA.  Interferences are removed from the reaction mixture by extraction with dichloromethane.  A subsequent extraction with iso-butanol removes the derivatives.  The derivatives are then back-extracted into a borax solution in preparation for analysis by high performance liquid chromatography.

An aliquot of the water sample is reacted with dinitrofluoro-benzene (DNFB) to form derivatives of glyphosate and AMPA.  Interferences are removed from the reaction mixture by extraction with dichloromethane.  A subsequent extraction with iso-butanol removes the derivatives.  The derivatives are then back-extracted into a borax solution in preparation for analysis by high performance liquid chromatography.

The sample is extracted with dichloromethane in a separatory funnel.  The extract is dried, then reduced to a known volume.  The final extract is then analyzed with capillary column gas chromatography with flame ionization detection.  The results are determined by obtaining the total area under the chromato-graphic curve between n-C10 and n-C30, then quantifying by external calibration.
Freon extract,IR absorb.

The sample is extracted with 1,1,2-trichloro-1,2,2-trifluoroethane in a separatory funnel.  The extract is diluted to a known volume, and analyzed with an infrared spectro-photometer.  The result is calculated by comparison of the absorbance of the sample extract to that of a prepared standard mixture.  When a silica gel clean-up step is incorporated into this procedure, it is referred to as Total Petroleum Hydrocarbons (TPH) rather than as Total Extractable Hydrocarbon.

Particulates are separated from the sample by filtration and then extracted with hexane using a Soxhlet extractor.  The liquid phase is then extracted with hexane and this extract is subsequently combined with the Soxhlet extract.  The hexane is evaporated from the combined extract and the residue is weighed.

The water sample is acidified and extracted with dichloro-methane. The raw extract is concentrated and drivatized with diazomethane to produce the corresponding methyl ester derivatives. (Suitable substitute derivatives may be produced by other available techniques.) If required, the extracts are cleaned up by Florisil column chromatography. The derivatives are analyzed by gas chromatography with flame ionization detection. Resin acid components summed.

Determination of Polychloriated Biphenyls (PCBs) In Soil by GC/ECD.  PURPOSE/PRINCIPLE OF METHOD: This document details the requirements and procedures for the analysis of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) in soil by gas chromatography  electron capture detector (GC/ECD).  A homogenized soil sample is extracted using dichloromethane (DCM). The extract may be cleaned up using column chromatography with 2% Deactivated Florisil. When contamination with sulphur is suspected, further cleanup using copper is required. Analysis is performed using a GC/ECD.  Similar methods have been developed for other matrices including waste and transformer oils, water, swabs, florisil tubes, biota. Generally, the sample extraction procedures differ while the GC analysis methods are similar or identical for all matrices. SCOPE: This procedure describes the determination of PCBs in soil and sediments. Other materials such as wood waste may also be analyzed by this method.  DETECTION LIMITS: Target Compound Reported Detection Limit (mg/g) Arochlor 1242 0.03, Arochlor 1248 0.03, Arochlor 1254 0.03, Arochlor 1260 0.03, INTERFERENCES: Interferences (e.g. co-eluting peaks on the chromatogram) may be due to sulphur, phthalate esters, or from chlorinated compounds. Suspect samples must be reanalyzed using appropriate cleanup steps. SAMPLE HANDLING & PRESERVATION: Sample Requirements: Whenever possible, samples must completely fill the bottle such that little or no headspace is present to eliminate the loss of volatile hydrocarbon components. (~125g of sample) Sample Containers: Glass jars that have been solvent rinsed with acetone then hexane, then dried. Shipment and Storage: Samples are to be refrigerated (at 42C) during shipping and prior to analysis. Samples suspected to contain high levels of analyte are to be segregated from other samples. Holding Time: Holding time prior to extraction is 14 days. REFERENCE: U.S. EPA Method 8080: Organochlorine Pesticides and PCBs Analysis.

DETECTION LIMITS: Target Compound Reported Detection Limit (mg/g) Arochlor 1242 0.03, Arochlor 1248 0.03, Arochlor 1254 0.03, Arochlor 1260 0.03, INTERFERENCES: Interferences (e.g. co-eluting peaks on the chromatogram) may be due to sulphur, phthalate esters, or from chlorinated compounds. Suspect samples must be reanalyzed using appropriate cleanup steps. SAMPLE HANDLING & PRESERVATION: Sample Requirements: Whenever possible, samples must completely fill the bottle such that little or no headspace is present to eliminate the loss of volatile hydrocarbon components. (~125g of sample) Sample Containers: Glass jars that have been solvent rinsed with acetone then hexane, then dried. Shipment and Storage: Samples are to be refrigerated (at 42C) during shipping and prior to analysis. Samples suspected to contain high levels of analyte are to be segregated from other samples. Holding Time: Holding time prior to extraction is 14 days. REFERENCE: U.S. EPA Method 8080: Organochlorine Pesticides and PCBs Analysis.

Determination of Polychloriated Biphenyls (PCBs) In Soil by GC/ECD.  PURPOSE/PRINCIPLE OF METHOD: This document details the requirements and procedures for the analysis of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) in soil by gas chromatography  electron capture detector (GC/ECD).  A homogenized soil sample is extracted using dichloromethane (DCM). The extract may be cleaned up using column chromatography with 2% Deactivated Florisil. When contamination with sulphur is suspected, further cleanup using copper is required. Analysis is performed using a GC/ECD.  Similar methods have been developed for other matrices including waste and transformer oils, water, swabs, florisil tubes, biota. The sample is analyzed by purge and trap gas chromatography with detection by mass spectrometry.  The procedure involves purging the volatile compounds from the sample with an inert gas, and trapping them on a solid sorbent.  When purging of the sample is complete, the trap is heated and the compounds are transferred to the gas chromatographic column.  Analysis is then accomplished by separation of the components by gas chromatography with detection by mass spectrometry.

This method describes the selective isolation of total coliforms and E.coli from drinking water. Colilert medium is added to water samples and incubated for 18 - 24 hours at 35 degrees C for growth of total coliforms and E.coli. Colilert may be used as a presence/absence (P-A) or semi-quantitative 5 tube multiple tube fermentation (MPN) test.

This method describes a multiple tube fermentation technique which estimates the Most Probable Number (MPN) in solids, soil, and sludge or diluted samples of blended shellfish. The MPN method is not influenced by turbidity.

Living bioluminescent bacteria are exposed to a test sample, and the toxic effect of the sample on the organisms is measured.  The Microtox test system measures the light output of rehydrated lyophilized bacteria after exposure to a specified dilution series of a sample, and compares it to the light output of a control blank (i.e./bacterial cell suspension in diluent only).  It is assumed that the difference in light production is due to the effect of the sample.  The degree of light loss (degree of metabolic inhibition in the bacteria) indicates the degree of toxicity of the sample and the IC50 is determined by a dose-response curve.  The IC50 is defined as the statistically determined concentration of a sample causing a 50% decrease in the light emission of Microtox bacteria Vibrio fischeri (formerly Photobacterium phosphoreum) under defined conditions of exposure time (usually 5 minutes or 15 minutes) and test temperature.  Note that fresh water samples are osmotically adjusted.  However, there should be no adjustment for pH nor for colour.

The sample is subjected to a weak acid [zinc acetate] reflux digestion to liberate hydrogen cyanide.  The resulting HCN is distilled from the digestion mixture and trapped in a weak NaOH solution.  This basic solution is then analyzed colorimetrically, ref. Isonicotinic - Barbituric Acid method.

This analysis is done using procedures adapted from EPA Method 445.0.  Chlorophyll-a is determined by a routine acetone extraction followed with analysis by fluorometry using the non-acidification procedure.  This method is not subject to interferences from chlorophyll b.  Note: Biota samples are typically submitted as scrapings on a filter.

A sulfur dioxide detector functions as the TRS detector.  The SO2 present in the stack sample is removed by a dry-base Sulfur Dioxide Regenerative Scrubber that removes only the SO2 present in the sample gas.  The TRS compounds present in the sample gas are then converted to SO2 by a thermal oxidizer where all the reduced sulfur compounds are oxidized quantitatively to SO2.
The SO2 analyzer measures sulfur dioxide concentrations using the principle of fluorescence of the SO2 molecule.  SO2 molecules are irradiated by light in the far-ultraviolet (UV) region and fluorescence with a secondary emission, also in the UV region.  This secondary emission gives off a light output that is proportional to the concentration of sulfur dioxide molecules present.
Bleached Pulp

The unfiltered sample is buffered at pH 7.4 so as to inhibit conversion of organic nitrogen compounds to ammonia and yet provide an alkaline medium which allows for the recovery of free ammonia by distillation into boric acid solution.  The ammonia in the distillate is then determined either by Nesslerization (low conc. 0.01 to 1.2 mg/L as N) or by titration (conc. 1. to 30. mg/L as N).  Preferably fresh samples are analyzed without preservation.  Where samples cannot be analyzed immediately they are acidified to pH 1.5 to 2 with H2SO4 and are analyzed within 36 hours of sample collection.

Sediment Fixed Residue (SFR) represents the solids or ash remaining after ignition at 550 C.  Sediment Volatile Residue (SVR) is the difference between the weight lost on ignition at 550 C and the weight of the sample dried at 105 C.  SVR is a rough approximation of the amount of organic matter in the sediment.

Sediment Fixed Residue (SFR) represents the solids or ash remaining after ignition at 550 C.  Sediment Volatile Residue (SVR) is the difference between the weight lost on ignition at 550 C and the weight of the sample dried at 105 C.  SVR is a rough approximation of the amount of organic matter in the sediment.
Observed Property ID: Residue: Total Fixed (Total Solids; Fixed) (mass conc.)

Method Name: Unseeded Dil No Nit Inh 5 day
Method Description: The biochemical oxygen demand is determined by measuring the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) that is consumed in the sample under aerobic conditions during the incubation period (five days at 20 C).  A polarographic membrane electrode that has been calibrated in saturated air is used to acquire all dissolved oxygen measurements.  No nitrogen inhibitor added.  No seed is added.  A modified Winkler procedure may be substituted for the DO probe procedure. Performance Base Method published circa Dec. 2000.

Method Name: Unseeded Dil No Nit Inh 5 day
Method Description: The biochemical oxygen demand is determined by measuring the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) that is consumed in the sample under aerobic conditions during the incubation period (five days at 20 C).  A polarographic membrane electrode that has been calibrated in saturated air is used to acquire all dissolved oxygen measurements.  No nitrogen inhibitor added.  No seed is added.  A modified Winkler procedure may be substituted for the DO probe procedure. Performance Base Method published circa Dec. 2000.
Observed Property ID: Carbenaceous plus nitrogenous Biochemical Oxygen Demand (fl. conc.)

A polarographic membrane electrode that has been calibrated in saturated air is used to acquire all dissolved oxygen measurements.  No nitrogen inhibitor added.  A modified Winkler procedure may be substituted for the DO probe procedure. Performance Base Method published circa Dec. 2000.

Method Description: A 10.4 cm (4.1") diameter polyethylene canister containing a collection medium is exposed to the ambient air for a period of approximately 30 days.  The sample subsequently undergoes gravimetric and/or chemical analysis in the laboratory with intermediate results reported in units of mg and loading results reported with units of mg/d m2/d.

A 10.4 cm (4.1") diameter polyethylene canister containing a collection medium is exposed to the ambient air for a period of approximately 30 days.  The sample subsequently undergoes gravimetric and/or chemical analysis in the laboratory with intermediate results reported in units of mg and loading results reported with units of mg/d m2/d.

A measured volume of sample is filtered through a 0.45 um membrane filter or a pre-rinsed, dried and pre-weighed glass fibre filter.  The filter is rinsed, removed from the filtration apparatus and dried at 105 C to constant weight, cooled in a desiccator and weighed.  The residue is next ignited at 550 C for 1 hour, then cooled, rewetted to restore water of hydration of minerals, re-dried at 105 C to constant weight, cooled in a desiccator and reweighed.  Volatile Biomass is the difference between the initial and fixed weights.  Intermediate results should be reported in units of mg(i.e., mg for whole sample) but final results should be reported either in mg/L or mg/m2, whichever is appropriate.

Organic and oxidizable inorganic substances are oxidized by potassium dichromate in H2SO4 solution at reflux temperature for 2 hours in a closed reflux.  Oxygen consumption is measured colorimetrically against standards at 600nm.

BrCl is used in a cold oxidation procedure to oxidize mercury, including organo-mercury compounds.  Note that there is no type of digestion prior to the BrCl oxidation.  Also, the organo-mercury compounds may not fully oxidize.  The oxidized mercury is then reduced to mercury vapour using stannous chloride, and the mercury analyzed by CVAAS at 253.7 nm.

The sample is digested with HNO3.  The pH of the solution is adjusted to 1.6, Br2 water is added, and the solution warmed until the Br2 colour vanishes.  The pH of the solution is then adjusted to 3.5 with a buffer solution, ammonium pyrrolidine dithiocarbarnate solution is added, and the solution is extracted.  The solvent layer is aspirated.  The absorbance is measured spectrophotometrically at 358.0 mu and compared with those of identically prepared standard Cr207 ion solution an acetylene-air reducing flame is used.

Organic and oxidizable inorganic substances are oxidized by potassium dichromate in H2SO4 solution at reflux temperature for 2 hours.  Excess dichromate is titrated with standard ferrous ammonium sulfate (0.1M) using orthophenanthroline ferrous complex (ferroin) as indicator.  Closed Reflux.

Volatile petroleum hydrocarbons (nC5-nC11) are extracted from samples using methanol. The methanol is analyzed using a purge and trap technique. Using purge and trap analysis, the volatile compounds are purged with an inert gas, adsorbed on a sorbent trap, and then desorbed into a capillary gas chromatograph with flame ionization detector. VPH results are corrected for BETX concentrations and percent moisture. Superceded Dec. 2000.

Volatile petroleum hydrocarbons (nC5-nC11) are extracted from samples using methanol. The methanol is analyzed using a purge and trap technique. Using purge and trap analysis, the volatile compounds are purged with an inert gas, adsorbed on a sorbent trap, and then desorbed into a capillary gas chromatograph with flame ionization detector. VPH results are corrected for BETX concentrations and percent moisture. Superceded Dec. 2000.

Colourimetry using heteropoly blue method on an autoanalyzer.  If turbid the sample is passed through a 0.45 u membrane filter.  If the sample is sea water all standard SIO2 solutions are prepared with synthetic sea water instead of distilled water.  A filtrate aliquot is mixed with a solution of (NH4)6MO7O24 in dil. H2SO4.  This mixture is then mixed with oxalic acid solution, followed by a 1-Amino-2-Naphthol-4-Sul-Phonic acid solution, containing NA2SO3 and NAHSO3.  The resulting heteropoly blue colour is measured spectrophotometrically at 660 mu and compared with identically prepared standard SIO2 solutions.  Similar to ascorbic acid method, but using 1-Amino-2-Naphthol-4-Sulphuric acid as the reducing agent.
This method measures the time (in hours) to 50% mortality in 100% concentration.
Rainbow trout, %survival after 96 hrs. Sample is adjusted for pH and hardness without dilution to within +/- 10% of the receiving water.

UV absorption is a useful surrogate measure of selected organic constituents in fresh waters,salt waters and waste water. Sample pH may be adjusted with HCl or NaOH. In poorly buffered samples, an appropriate non-UV-absorbing buffer system such as a phosphate buffer may be used. Once the sample pH has been measured/adjusted, filter sample.  Equilibrate spectrophotometer and measure  UV absorbance at 253.7 nm of at least two filtered portions at room temperature.

HNO3 preserved water samples are dispensed into pre-cleaned glass test tubes. Bromine monochloride (BrCl, a strong oxidant) is added to each sample to oxidize all mercury species (including organo-mercurais) to the Hg2+ state. The samples are left to cold digest for approx. 45 min.  Upon meeting the required digestion time the BrCl is quenched with Hydroxylamine hydrochloride (NH2OH-HCl, a weak reductant). These samples are allowed to sit again for approx. 45 min. in order for the BrCl to be completely consumed by the hydroxylamine. The Hg in the samples is reduced with stannous chloride dihydrate (SnCl2-2H2O, a strong reductant) to its elemental state and instrumental analysis is performed using a cold vapor atomic fluoresence spectrophotometer.

The Hg in the samples is reduced with stannous chloride dihydrate (SnCl2-2H2O, a strong reductant) to its elemental state and instrumental analysis is performed using a cold vapor atomic fluoresence spectrophotometer.

Place a sterile absorbent pad in the lid of a sterile culture dish and pipet at least 2.0 mL lauryl tryptose broth, prepared as directed in 9221B.1.a1), to saturate pad.  Carefully remove any excess liquid from absorbent pad by decanting plate.  Aseptically place filter through which the sample has been passed on pad.  Incubate filter, without inverting dish, for 1.5 to 2h at 35 +/- 0.5 degree C in an atmosphere of at least 60% relative humidity.

Method Name: Metals in Biota (dry): total: acid digestion: ICP-SFMS
Method Description: 0.1 gram of dried, homogenized biota is weighed in a microwave TFM vessel, and 8mL of Nitric Acid and 1mL of Hydrogen Peroxide are added. The sample is digested at 200 degrees C for 15 minutes in a closed vessel high pressure microwave oven.  The sample is cooled, the volume adjusted to 100mL and introduced to an iductively coupled argon plasma-sector field mass spectrometer (ICP-SFMS) by pneumatic nebulization.  Each respective element is measured at a specific mass to charge ratio, m/z value expressed in amu (atomic mass units), and at a specified instrument resolution. LR: Low Resolution ~300, MR: Mid Resolution ~4000 and HR: Hich Resolution ~10000.  Ref: Method number 02-2705, National Laboratory for Environmental Testing, CCIW, Environment Canada, Burlington. Requested April 2003.

Method Description: One gram of wet, homogenized biota is weighed in a microwave TFM vessel, and 8mL of Nitric Acid and 1mL of Hydrogen Peroxide are added.  The sample is digested at 200 degrees C for 15 minutes in a closed vessel high pressure microwave oven.  The sample is cooled, the volume adjusted to 100mL and introduced to an inductively coupled argon plasma-sector field mass spectrometer (ICP-SFMS) by pneumatic nebulization.  Each respective element is measured at a specific mass to charge ratio, m/z value expressed in amu (atomic mass units), and at a specified instrument resolution.  LR: Low Resolution ~300, MR: Mid Resolution ~4000.  Ref: 02-2704, National Laboratory for Environmental Testing, CCIW, Environment Canada, Burlington. Requested April 2003.

The whole water sample is collected in a HDPE/Teflon bottle.  In a Class 100 workstation it is preserved with concentrated Nitric Acid at concentration of 0.2 percent (v/v).  The acid preservative extracts the metals from material in the sample and a decanted portion is introduced directly to an inductively coupled argon plasma-sector field mass spectrometer (ICP-SFMS) by pneumatic nebulization.  Each respective element is measured at a specific mass to charge ratio, m/z value expressed in amu (atomic mass units), and at a specified instrument resolution.  LR: Low Resolution ~300, MR: Mid Resolution ~4000 and HR: High Resolution ~10000.  Ref: Method number 02-2061, National Laboratory for Environmental Testing, CCIW, Environment Canada, Burlington. Requested April 2003.

Each respective element is measured at a specific mass to charge ratio, m/z value expressed in amu (atomic mass units), and at a specified instrument resolution.  LR: Low Resolution ~300, MR: Mid Resolution ~4000 and HR: High Resolution ~10000.  Ref: Method number 02-2061, National Laboratory for Environmental Testing, CCIW, Environment Canada, Burlington. Requested April 2003.

Method Name: Metals in water: total: "in-bottle" digestion: ICP-SFMS
Method Description: The whole water sample collected in a HDPE/Teflon bottle, is de-capped in a Class 100 workstation, acidified to 2% (v/v) HNO3 and 1% (v/v) HCl and recapped.  The sample is "in-bottle" digested in a convection oven, set at 60 degrees C for 16 hours.  The sample is cooled and introduced to an inductively coupled argon plasma-sector field mass spectrometer (ICP-SFMS) by pneumatic nebulization.  Each respective element is measured at a specific mass to charge ratio, m/z value expressed in amu (atomic mass units), and at resolution.  LR: Low Resolution ~300, MR: Mid Resolution ~4000 and HR: High a specified instrument Resolution ~10000.  Ref: Method number 02-2003, National Laboratory for Environmental Testing, CCIW, Environment Canada, Burlington. Requested April 2003.

Method Name: Metals in water: dissolved: "in-bottle" digestion: ICP-SFMS
Method Description: The whole water sample is filtered through a 0.45 micron cellulose acetate filter paper and the filtrate is stored in a HDPE/Teflon bottle.  The container is de-capped in a Class 100 workstation, acidified to 2% (v/v) HNO3 and 1% (v/v) HCl and recapped.  The sample is "in-bottle" digested in a convection oven, set at 60 degrees C for 16 hours.  The sample is cooled and introduced to an inductively coupled argon plasma-sector field mass spectrometer (ICP-SFMS) by pneumatic nebulization.  Each respective element is measured at a specific mass to charge ratio, m/z value expressed in amu (atomic mass units), and at a specified intrument resolution.  LR: Low Resolution ~300, MR: Mid Resolution ~4000 and HR: High Resolution ~10000.  Ref: Method number 02-2003, National Laboratory for Environmental Testing, CCIW, Environment Canada, Burlington, Requested April 2003.

Hach MnIII COD method uses the oxidant trivalent manganese. Sodium bismuthate is used to remove chloride interferences. Using a vacuum pump, an acidified homogenized sample is filtered through a glass fiber filter, then through sodium bismuthate into a vial containing the trivalent manganese solution. The glass fiber filter traps solids and is removed from the filter and placed into the MnIII vial. The capped vial is digested at 150 degrees C for 1 hour. As the MnIII oxidizes the organics present in the sample, the purple color of the MnIII solution decreases, becoming clear when all MnIII has been reduced. The COD concentration is proportional to the decrease in the purple color of the solution. COD is determined colorimetrically at 510 nm using a calibration curve from potassium hydrogen phthalate standards.

Method Name: Metals in Biota (wet): total: acid digestion: ICP-MS
Method Description: Five grams of wet, homogenized biota is weighed in a centrifuge tube, and 2.5 mL of Nitric Acid and 2.5 mL of Hydrochloric acid are added.  The sample is digested at room temperature for one hour and then digested at 90-95 degrees C in a water bath or heat block for one more hour.  The sample is cooled and the volume is made to 50 mL with DI.  The digestate is then diluted at ten fold and introduced to a collision/reaction cell inductively coupled argon plasma mass spectrometer (CRC ICPMS) by pneumatic nebulization.  Each respective element is measured at a specific mass to charge ratio, m/z value expressed in amu (atomic mass units).  -  Maxxam Analytics (BC).  Added to EMS Dec 10, 2008.

The digestate is then diluted at ten fold and introduced to a collision/reaction cell inductively coupled argon plasma mass spectrometer (CRC ICPMS) by pneumatic nebulization.  Each respective element is measured at a specific mass to charge ratio, m/z value expressed in amu (atomic mass units).  -  Maxxam Analytics (BC).  Added to EMS Dec 10, 2008.

Method Name: Total metals: FA: HNO3: HR-ICPMS (No Prep)Prep)
Method Description: Ultra trace metals in water are analyzed by high resolution inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (HR-ICPMS), modified from US EPA 200.8, (Revision 5.5).  The detection limits provided can only be met for undigested samples.  This procedure is intended for colorless, non-turbid, acid-preserved water samples (i.e. pristine water samples), having turbidity < 1 NTU and no odor.  Where turbidity exceeds 1 NTU, and/or the sample is colored and has an odor, results may be biased low compared to true Total Metals concentrations.  ALS recommends that turbidity analysis be requested on samples submitted for this test to aid with interpretation of results.

The detection limits provided can only be met for undigested samples.  This procedure is intended for colorless, non-turbid, acid-preserved water samples (i.e. pristine water samples), having turbidity < 1 NTU and no odor.  Where turbidity exceeds 1 NTU, and/or the sample is colored and has an odor, results may be biased low compared to true Total Metals concentrations.  ALS recommends that turbidity analysis be requested on samples submitted for this test to aid with interpretation of results.

Method Name: Dissolved metals: FF: FA: HNO3: HR-ICPMS
Method Description: Ultra trace metals in water are analyzed by high resolution inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (HR-ICPMS), based on US EPA Method 200.8, (Oct. 1999). This procedure is intended for pristine field-filtered acid-preserved water samples.  The detection limits (LOR) for this test are based on lab instrumental analysis only, not including filtration. ALS-supplied field filtration equipment does not support these LOR. Therefore, because of the high probability of false positives due to filtration, it is strongly recommended that a filtration blank be analyzed to aid in data interpretation.

This procedure is intended for pristine field-filtered acid-preserved water samples.  The detection limits (LOR) for this test are based on lab instrumental analysis only, not including filtration. ALS-supplied field filtration equipment does not support these LOR. Therefore, because of the high probability of false positives due to filtration, it is strongly recommended that a filtration blank be analyzed to aid in data interpretation.

Same as X044, but higher MDL.  A clear (Total) or filtered (Dissolved) water sample is injected into a stream of carbonate-bicarbonate eluent and passed through a series of ion exchanger.  The anions of interested are separated on the basis of their relative affinities for a low capacity , strongly basic anion exchanger (guard and separate columns).  The separated anions are directed through the anion self-regenerating suppressor (ASRS).  Hydronium ions in the suppressor will neutralize the eluent to its weakly ionized form and convert the separated anions in their conductive acid form.  The separated anions are measured by conductivity.  They are identified on the basis of retention time as compared to standards.  Quantitation is by measurement of peak area of peak height against a calibration curve generated from known standards.

The pH of a filtered sample is adjusted to pH 7.6.  Then the TAC is measured by integrating the absorbance of the sample between 400 and 700 nm.  One unit of TAC is defined as the colour produced by 2 mg/L platinum in the form of the chloroplatinate ion.

Method Description: A small polypropylene beaker containing about 40 mL of sample is placed in a constant-temperature water bath until it attains 25.0(+/-)0.5 C.  The beaker is then loaded onto a sample tray and the pH is measured potentiometrically using a combined glass/reference electrode (Ag/AgCl as the reference half-cell) that has been calibrated against two certified reference buffer solutions; the calibration standards are chosen to bracket the sample pH as closely as possible.  This method is not appropriate for low ionic strength solutions nor for solutions having pH below pH2 nor above pH 12.
